subject: Re: Could you qualify for loan forgiveness?
body:
I don’t think I worked there long enough

Sent from my iPhone 


> On Jun 28, 2022, at 2:56 PM, Ifeoma Ahuna <ifyahuna@gmail.com> wrote:
> 
> ﻿
> 
> maybe because you worked for UTD?
> 
> 
> ---------- Forwarded message ---------
> From: Nelnet Student Loan Servicing <Help@e.nelnet.net>
> Date: Tue, Jun 28, 2022 at 11:12 AM
> Subject: Could you qualify for loan forgiveness?
> To: <ifyahuna@gmail.com>
> 
> 
> If you've worked in public service, you may be eligible.
> View Online
>  	
> 
> LOG IN
> 	IFEOMA
> Account: EXXXXX5473
> 	 	
>  
>  	
> How to Take Advantage of the Limited PSLF Waiver
> Dear IFEOMA,
> 
> We want to make you aware of a temporary initiative from the U.S. Department of Education’s office of Federal Student Aid (FSA) that could bring you closer to qualifying for student loan forgiveness.
> 
> What’s it all about?
> Under the limited Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) waiver — which lasts until October 31, 2022 — if you’ve worked in public service (for example, for a nonprofit organization or government agency*), you may be eligible to receive credit toward PSLF for additional past periods of repayment. Any period of repayment after October 1, 2007, will count as a qualifying payment, regardless of loan program, repayment plan, or whether the payment was made in full or on time. The qualifying public service employment requirement has not changed.
> 
> In general, the PSLF Program forgives the remaining balance on a borrower’s Direct Loan(s) after the borrower has made 120 qualifying payments (or the equivalent) while working full-time for a qualifying employer. Now borrowers can get credit for previously ineligible payments, allowing them to receive PSLF sooner.
> 
> * Please note that government agencies include all levels — federal, state, local, and tribal. Federal service includes U.S. military — so servicemembers are encouraged to apply. In addition, for teachers who have already received Teacher Loan Forgiveness, under the limited PSLF waiver (until October 31, 2022), the period of service that led to your eligibility for that forgiveness will count toward PSLF if you certify employment for PSLF for that period — so you’re also encouraged to apply.
> 
> Who is eligible?
> The changes under the waiver apply to:
> 
> Those who consolidate other federal loans into the Direct Loan Program by October 31, 2022
> Those with Direct Loans who have never submitted a PSLF form
> Those with Direct Loans who have already submitted a PSLF form
> Periods of repayment on parent PLUS loans are not eligible under the limited PSLF waiver.
> 
> Read further to see which category applies to you and what actions you may need to take.
> 
> I have a Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL), Perkins, or other federal student loan(s). What do I need to do?
> If this describes your situation, you may have previously applied for PSLF and been denied because of your loan type. We encourage you to verify eligible employment and apply for PSLF again (using FSA’s PSLF Help Tool). You’ll also need to consolidate your loans into a Direct Consolidation Loan to qualify for PSLF — however, what's different under the limited PSLF waiver is that consolidation doesn't "reset your clock" and you get credit for payments made before you consolidated your loans. You must consolidate into the Direct Loan Program and apply for PSLF by October 31, 2022, to take advantage of the waiver.
> 
> I have a Direct loan(s) but I’ve never applied for PSLF. What happens after I apply? 
> If this describes your situation, you should apply before the waiver ends for maximum benefit. Apply for PSLF (using FSA’s PSLF Help Tool) and verify eligible employment by October 31, 2022. Since you already have a Direct loan(s), you will not need to consolidate to qualify.
> After you submit your first PSLF form, your loans transfer to another federal student loan servicer that manages the PSLF Program. Beginning early summer 2022, Federal Student Aid (FSA) will start transitioning the PSLF Program, borrowers, and their loans from FedLoan Servicing to MOHELA. Transfers will start in early July and run through the summer, with all transfers completed by the end of September 2022.
> 
> PSLF borrowers whose loans have not been forgiven will be transferred to MOHELA. If you submit your first PSLF form after May 1, 2022, and your loans are not forgiven at that time, you can expect your loans to transfer to MOHELA after July 1, 2022. You will receive a welcome letter from MOHELA after your loans transfer and then you will be able to create your online account with MOHELA and start checking on your progress toward PSLF. Please note, these transfers will be completed incrementally and not all information will be transferred or available immediately on July 1.
> 
> PSLF forgiveness for borrowers who meet all eligibility requirements will continue to occur during this transfer timeframe. PSLF borrowers whose loans are forgiven during this timeframe will not be transferred.
> 
> 
> I have a Direct Loan(s) and already submitted a PSLF form. What happens next? 
> In this case, you will automatically receive credit for prior — and now eligible — periods of repayment while working for a qualifying employer. You will be notified when your payment count has been updated. The only reason to submit a PSLF form in this case is if you have a previous period of employment that hasn’t been certified. It’s important for you to verify the types of federal student loans you have by logging in to FSA’s Aid Summary with your FSA ID. If you also have non-Direct Loans with coinciding periods of eligible employment, you must consolidate into the Direct Loan Program and apply for PSLF by October 31, 2022, to take advantage of the waiver.
> With regard to your employment history, whether you’re applying for PSLF for the first time or updating your PSLF eligibility, make sure you complete your Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) & Temporary Expanded PSLF (TEPSLF) Certification & Application (PSLF form) by October 31, 2022. We recommend you apply online using the PSLF Help Tool and report every job you’ve had with a nonprofit or government organization since October 1, 2007.
> 
> Unsure about your loan types? 
> You can log in to FSA’s Aid Summary using your FSA ID to find out what types of federal student loans you have.
> 
> Have questions about consolidation?
> If you are uncertain about whether you have worked or work for a qualifying employer, you should make that determination first and/or review the benefits and considerations before making the decision to consolidate your loans. We are happy to discuss whether consolidation would allow you to benefit under the limited PSLF waiver. We can also guide you through the online consolidation process.
> 
> After your consolidation loan is made, you should go back to FSA’s PSLF Help Tool to certify all periods of qualifying employment.
> 
> Where can I find out more?
> We know there’s a lot of information to digest when it comes to forgiveness. We want to help! Nelnet has handy resources you can tap for more information — we highly recommend our limited PSLF waiver webpage and a handy, downloadable resource written by FSA and packaged by Nelnet called Top 10 Tips About the Limited PSLF Waiver.
> 
> Beware of scams!
> Borrowers have reported hearing from so-called student debt relief companies offering assistance with these new initiatives – for a fee. You should not have to pay for assistance, and, as your student loan servicer, Nelnet provides guidance for free. Call us instead!
> 
> Questions? We’re here for you. Visit Nelnet.com or call us at 888.486.4722.
> 
> 
> Sincerely,
> 
> Your Nelnet Customer Service Team

subject: Fwd: Could you qualify for loan forgiveness?
body:
maybe because you worked for UTD?


---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Nelnet Student Loan Servicing <Help@e.nelnet.net>
Date: Tue, Jun 28, 2022 at 11:12 AM
Subject: Could you qualify for loan forgiveness?
To: <ifyahuna@gmail.com>


*If you've worked in public service, you may be eligible.*
*View Online*
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/servlet/MailView?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
  [image: Nelnet Logo]
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=3&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
Log in
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=21&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>

IFEOMA

*Account:* EXXXXX5473



How to Take Advantage of the Limited PSLF Waiver

Dear IFEOMA,

We want to make you aware of a temporary initiative from the U.S.
Department of Education’s office of Federal Student Aid (FSA) that could
bring you closer to qualifying for student loan forgiveness.

*What’s it all about?*
Under the limited Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) waiver
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=17&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
*—
which lasts until October 31, 2022 —* if you’ve worked in public service
(for example, for a nonprofit organization or government agency*), you may
be eligible to receive credit toward PSLF
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=28&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
for additional past periods of repayment. Any period of repayment after
October 1, 2007, will count as a qualifying payment, regardless of loan
program, repayment plan, or whether the payment was made in full or on
time. The qualifying public service employment requirement
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=15&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
has *not* changed.

In general, the PSLF Program forgives the remaining balance on a borrower’s
Direct Loan(s) after the borrower has made 120 qualifying payments (or the
equivalent) while working full-time for a qualifying employer. Now
borrowers can get credit for previously ineligible payments, allowing them
to receive PSLF sooner.

* Please note that government agencies include all levels — federal, state,
local, and tribal. Federal service includes U.S. military — so
servicemembers are encouraged to apply. In addition, for teachers who have
already received Teacher Loan Forgiveness, under the limited PSLF waiver
(until October 31, 2022), the period of service that led to your
eligibility for that forgiveness will count toward PSLF if you certify
employment for PSLF for that period — so you’re also encouraged to apply.

* Who is eligible?*
The changes under the waiver apply to:

   - Those who consolidate other federal loans into the Direct Loan Program
   by October 31, 2022
   - Those with Direct Loans who have never submitted a PSLF form
   - Those with Direct Loans who have already submitted a PSLF form

Periods of repayment on parent PLUS loans are not eligible under the
limited PSLF waiver.

Read further to see which category applies to you and what actions you may
need to take.

   - *I have a Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL), Perkins, or other
   federal student loan(s). What do I need to do?*
   *If this describes your situation, you may have previously applied for
   PSLF and been denied because of your loan type.* We encourage you to
   verify eligible employment and apply for PSLF again (using FSA’s PSLF
   Help Tool
   <http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=30&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>).
   You’ll also need to consolidate your loans into a Direct Consolidation
   Loan
   <http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=6&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
   to qualify for PSLF — however, what's different under the limited PSLF
   waiver is that consolidation doesn't "reset your clock" and you get credit
   for payments made before you consolidated your loans. You must consolidate
   into the Direct Loan Program and apply for PSLF by October 31, 2022, to
   take advantage of the waiver.
   - *I have a Direct loan(s) but I’ve never applied for PSLF. What happens
   after I apply? *
   *If this describes your situation, you should apply before the waiver
   ends for maximum benefit.* Apply for PSLF (using FSA’s PSLF Help Tool
   <http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=30&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>)
   and verify eligible employment by October 31, 2022. Since you already have
   a Direct loan(s), you will not need to consolidate to qualify.

   After you submit your first PSLF form, your loans transfer to another
   federal student loan servicer that manages the PSLF Program. Beginning
   early summer 2022, Federal Student Aid (FSA) will start transitioning the
   PSLF Program, borrowers, and their loans from FedLoan Servicing
   <http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=4&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
   to MOHELA
   <http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=13&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>.
   Transfers will start in early July and run through the summer, with all
   transfers completed by the end of September 2022.

   PSLF borrowers whose loans *have not been forgiven* will be transferred
   to MOHELA. If you submit your first PSLF form after May 1, 2022, and your
   loans are not forgiven at that time, you can expect your loans to transfer
   to MOHELA after July 1, 2022. You will receive a welcome letter from MOHELA
   after your loans transfer and then you will be able to create your online
   account with MOHELA and start checking on your progress toward PSLF. Please
   note, these transfers will be completed incrementally and not all
   information will be transferred or available immediately on July 1.

   PSLF forgiveness for borrowers who meet all eligibility requirements
   will continue to occur during this transfer timeframe. PSLF borrowers whose
   loans *are forgiven* during this timeframe will not be transferred.

   - *I have a Direct Loan(s) and already submitted a PSLF form. What
   happens next? *
   *In this case, you will automatically receive credit for prior — and now
   eligible — periods of repayment while working for a qualifying employer.
   You will be notified when your payment count has been updated.* The only
   reason to submit a PSLF form in this case is if you have a previous period
   of employment that hasn’t been certified. It’s important for you to verify
   the types of federal student loans you have by logging in to FSA’s Aid
   Summary
   <http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=19&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
   with your FSA ID. If you also have non-Direct Loans with coinciding periods
   of eligible employment, you must consolidate into the Direct Loan Program
   and apply for PSLF by October 31, 2022, to take advantage of the waiver.

With regard to your employment history, whether you’re applying for PSLF
for the first time or updating your PSLF eligibility, make sure you
complete your *Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) & Temporary Expanded
PSLF (TEPSLF) Certification & Application* (PSLF form) by October 31, 2022.
We recommend you apply online using the PSLF Help Tool
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=30&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
and report every job you’ve had with a nonprofit or government organization
since October 1, 2007.

*Unsure about your loan types? *
You can log in to FSA’s Aid Summary
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=19&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
using your FSA ID
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=35&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
to find out what types of federal student loans you have.

*Have questions about consolidation?*
If you are uncertain about whether you have worked or work for a qualifying
employer, you should make that determination first and/or review the
benefits and considerations before making the decision to consolidate your
loans. We are happy to discuss whether consolidation would allow you to
benefit under the limited PSLF waiver. We can also guide you through the online
consolidation process
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=32&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
.

After your consolidation loan is made, you should go back to FSA’s PSLF
Help Tool
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=30&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
to certify all periods of qualifying employment.

*Where can I find out more?*
We know there’s a lot of information to digest when it comes to
forgiveness. We want to help! Nelnet has handy resources you can tap for
more information — we highly recommend our limited PSLF waiver webpage
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=24&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
and a handy, downloadable resource written by FSA and packaged by Nelnet
called *Top 10 Tips About the Limited PSLF Waiver*
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=33&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
.

*Beware of scams!*
Borrowers have reported hearing from so-called student debt relief
companies offering assistance with these new initiatives – for a fee. You
should not have to pay for assistance, and, as your student loan servicer,
Nelnet provides guidance for free. Call us instead!

*Questions? We’re here for you.* Visit Nelnet.com
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=22&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
or
call us at 888.486.4722.

Sincerely,

Your Nelnet Customer Service Team


Log in to Your Account
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=40&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>

Make a Payment
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=37&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
Repayment Options
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=41&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>



To ensure delivery to your inbox, please add Help@e.Nelnet.net to your
address book.

This email was sent to: ifyahuna@gmail.com

This email was sent by: *Nelnet, Inc*
121 South 13th Street, Lincoln, NE 68508, USA

EM-1071-0622
Email <Help@Nelnet.net>
Facebook
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=26&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>
Twitter
<http://links.nelnet.mkt8018.com/ctt?ms=MjY5Njg4MDgS1&kn=27&r=NzkyMDE1MzQyODE2S0&b=0&j=MjI0MTg4MDA0MgS2&mt=1&rt=0>


--

> Good morning Ifeoma and Shaw,
>
> I hope you are enjoying your week.
>
> I wanted to follow up with this email after speaking with Shaw this
> morning. I had mistakenly mixed you up with another applicant when I

subject: Fwd: Teaware Stove Safe?
body:
Let me know if I should return it or not


---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: <support@artoftea.com>
Date: Tue, Jul 26, 2022 at 1:18 PM
Subject: Re: Teaware Stove Safe?
To: <ifyahuna@gmail.com>


Hello Ifeoma,

Thank you for getting back to us with a confirmation. This has since been
fully documented.

In regards to your query, we would not recommend putting the new colored
glasses or Kinto glass teapots on the stovetop at all - nor reheating them
in a microwave. While the glass is heat-resistant, the extreme and
sometimes sudden heat that emanates from a stovetop burner might crack or
break the glass. We suggest to solely use hot water to steep your tea
leaves inside the teapot and to add additional hot water as needed to
re-steep.

I hope this helps :)

Please reach out to us should you have additional questions or concerns.
We're always happy to assist.

In the meantime, the Art of Tea tea'm wishes you a wonderful day!

Stay happy, healthy, and safe.

Cheers,
Jenn

heat-resistant. Is that synonymous with it being on the stove for long
periods of time and being fine? Is it safe to put on a stove top?

Thanks for all your help 😊

body:
Welcome to Slack

Ta-da! You’ve joined your first Slack workspace and we couldn’t be more delighted. Here are your account details, along with some tips to help you get started.

Workspace name: TW Community

tw-community.slack.com []

Open Slack [https://tw-community.slack.com/x-p3845221068064-3821489120290-3870586123298/messages/C03Q5DN8YCA]
Tips for getting started

Take a quick tour

Get familiar with the basics of Slack [https://tw-community.slack.com/x-p3845221068064-3821489120290-3870586123298/resources/using-slack/your-quick-start-guide-to-slack?utm_medium=email&utm_source=confirmation-new-join] so you’re ready to get to work in no time.

Start working in channels

Keep conversations organized in channels [https://tw-community.slack.com/x-p3845221068064-3821489120290-3870586123298/features/channels?utm_medium=email&utm_source=confirmation-new-join] — organized spaces for everything related to a project, topic, or team.

Download Slack

For the best experience with Slack, download our apps [https://tw-community.slack.com/x-p3845221068064-3821489120290-3870586123298/downloads?utm_medium=email&utm_source=confirmation-new-join&t=T03QV6H201W] for desktop and mobile.

See more tips [https://tw-community.slack.com/x-p3845221068064-3821489120290-3870586123298/resources/using-slack/top-5-tips-for-getting-started-in-slack?utm_medium=email&utm_source=confirmation-new-join]

If you have any questions as you’re getting started, drop us a note at help@slack.com. We’re glad you’re here!

subject: Wavelet Transform
body:
Sara B.T. Thiel added comments and suggestions to the following document
Wavelet Transform  
(https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TCJ0hMrJ_8UXjaydl5eAJZrMMaQzwt8Be88UD1d3kz8/edit?usp=comment_email_document&ts=61f180fd&usp_dm=false)

New: 2 comments, 6 suggestions


New Comments

.
Sara B.T. Thiel
| Conclusion
We don't do conclusion sections on Built In, typically. I think this  
one-sentence wrap up should do nicely!

Reply (Reply  
<d+AORGpRczp1xtjvPJhhaVjplg3xYW2pB-3hn99C0mBN7HEgn8MJR5-p6JlLatx8o9OU0EbxSjs5Ntj7WC-1thid-X1-QUq94-C8FhaDdSugbdp1331JFQ3-oJA6qtAlgbdHlmfy9zm1wq@docs.google.com>)
Open  
(https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TCJ0hMrJ_8UXjaydl5eAJZrMMaQzwt8Be88UD1d3kz8/edit?disco=AAAAUhdqrEQ&usp=comment_email_discussion&ts=61f180fd&usp_dm=false)

.
Sara B.T. Thiel
| References
Great wavelet review: Addison, P.S. (2005). Wavelet transforms and the ecg:  
A review. Physiological Measurement, 26 (5), p. R155

Example inspired by:  
https://www.mathworks.com/help/wavelet/ug/r-wave-detection-in-the-ecg.html
We don't do reference sections. Are there any places above where we can  
embed links to these resources?

Reply (Reply  
<d+AORGpRd2x5JmplXE52PsjJHtJC2U5moupMJUWL_Y5vpdGtP5sfE_G2tO12NVPIzjuPGzgig58AKSVGLo1bvr8QvxIAzFdUvmq5VGMAeLVZ--AeJWe2WSDj4B5csgzdDHmeuVG_lkwP6u@docs.google.com>)
Open  
(https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TCJ0hMrJ_8UXjaydl5eAJZrMMaQzwt8Be88UD1d3kz8/edit?disco=AAAAUhdqrEU&usp=comment_email_discussion&ts=61f180fd&usp_dm=false)


New Suggestions

.
Sara B.T. Thiel
Replace: “W” with “w”

Reply (Reply

A review. Physiological Measurement, 26 (5), p. R155

Example inspired by:  
https://www.mathworks.com/help/wavelet/ug/r-wave-detection-in-the-ecg.html
We don't do reference sections. Are there any places above where we can  
embed links to these resources?

Shawhin
Sounds good. Maybe we can add a sentence at the very end for those who want  
to learn more?

Maybe like: For a deeper dive into the details of the wavelet transform,  
check out Addison's review (hyperlinked).

The mathworks reference is less important.

Sara B.T. Thiel

review? We can link the mathworks reference above. I'll find a place. More  
links are better anyway for SEO visibility!

New Comments

Sara B.T. Thiel
| Follow along as I discuss the key components of the wavelet transform and  
provide a step-by-step tutorial on how you can do it yourself.
I'm not sure any of this is the right language, Shaw, but I think we need a  
bit more of a "hook" in the subhead. Please edit me!

Shawhin
Agreed. Here are a few ideas.

- A step-by-step tutorial of the wavelet transform with example code for  
your next time series project

- Let's break down the wavelet transform and show you how to do it yourself.

- Learn how wavelet transforms work and how to do it yourself in this  
step-by-step tutorial.

Sara B.T. Thiel
I like number 3!

Hey Shaw! For SEO purposes, I'd like to include a snippet box that distills  
the difference between FT and WT in 2-4 sentences. Can you provide  
something I can include here?

Shawhin
How about this?

Fourier transforms breaks down signals into oscillations that persist over  
the entire sequence. Wavelet transforms perform a similar function, however  
they can break signals down into oscillations localized in space and time.

How about this?

Fourier transforms breaks down signals into oscillations that persist over  
the entire sequence. Wavelet transforms perform a similar function, however  
they can break signals down into oscillations localized in space and time.

subject: Updates to Discord’s Monetization Terms
body:
Hi there,

We wanted to let you know that we’re updating our Monetization Terms (https://csHCk04.na1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/WZ+113/csHCk04/VWZs4t2rxlcJW5-J09k1hxsw1W8DFYQL4YvrV9N5_C1nk3l0g5V1-WJV7CgVtZW40clDc2_5DmkW3SH1Xg6wGlZLW1DylZN52vcy7VWqPHL6hHr5lVBQ08854MxJKW2Qp_5k4xL0pZW3KHnDp5LyCS1W5KZgBf5WYsQlW7fb1YW6zf8TgW836qhH8CSVXYN3YMr7Njn1lPW1fGXXN4wCyg9VZG35-7rsZMxW3sxVMx4-79vHW7DHSH13hg3BBW8Yky313hlG1RW7GVsTP8qHgglW7R7QcR22Zb3SN863fmzN8BscVKDwvc7sGxcTN5t56d4JSPRWW8xzwJy8qjQmJW4nqz2z1VWD10W6Rfqkt1CnryBW89s7s72XTPS_W8qjb1G1ZyhZK39BM1 ) . We periodically make these updates as our business, and the services we offer you, grow. Transparency is important to us, and we want to let you know what’s changing ahead of time. Here are some highlights of what we’ve updated:

- iOS In-App Purchases for Server Subscriptions

Effective April 1, 2023, creators will be able to sell Server Subscriptions directly through our iOS app. We’ve updated our terms to address specific app store requirements, and have introduced a new fee structure to reflect the costs associated with in-app purchases.
- Changes to Creator Fees

Effective May 1, 2023, sales of Server Subscriptions on desktop and mobile will be subject to an updated fee structure. This includes the introduction of a new fee category to cover payment processing and transaction costs. We’re making these changes to ensure that we can continue to provide scalable services for creators at competitive prices.

We encourage you to read the updated documents (https://csHCk04.na1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/WZ+113/csHCk04/VWZs4t2rxlcJW5-J09k1hxsw1W8DFYQL4YvrV9N5_C1nk3l0g5V1-WJV7CgVtZW40clDc2_5DmkW3SH1Xg6wGlZLW1DylZN52vcy7VWqPHL6hHr5lVBQ08854MxJKW2Qp_5k4xL0pZW3KHnDp5LyCS1W5KZgBf5WYsQlW7fb1YW6zf8TgW836qhH8CSVXYN3YMr7Njn1lPW1fGXXN4wCyg9VZG35-7rsZMxW3sxVMx4-79vHW7DHSH13hg3BBW8Yky313hlG1RW7GVsTP8qHgglW7R7QcR22Zb3SN863fmzN8BscVKDwvc7sGxcTN5t56d4JSPRWW8xzwJy8qjQmJW4nqz2z1VWD10W6Rfqkt1CnryBW89s7s72XTPS_W8qjb1G1ZyhZK39BM1 ) in full. We appreciate you being an early adopter of Server Subscriptions. If you have any questions about this change you can reach out to us via our Creator Support center (https://csHCk04.na1.hubspotlinks.com/Ctc/WZ+113/csHCk04/VWZs4t2rxlcJW5-J09k1hxsw1W8DFYQL4YvrV9N5_C1mL3l0fwV1-WJV7CgZnsW91cyQQ39cyMpW3Rf-yD7RlRhLW2V-j7z3Bv7XyW3Kzw-B9jhq0MW6_rLyN8BQjZ-VzJpjg8-YHFXW124PTD3qHtqmW7mX29Q4__HgXW1sfj6t99h4LZW9kRHjL3C7XTYW4g5R4376krXrW1V11QX6BKhMdV_yHmv696g7bN8gRsRZd6nKzW5tthK97W48_VW2m3_Zh1kNnTdVbDsv72hqvBqN5W1NF7rZm7NW8tkFWC4L5C1sW4q7xhf6-BbdTVXZyNb7WL9fYW2YHGsF75cYrc33k91 ) .

subject: Your Discord subscription will soon be renewed!
body:
What's up shawhin,

We read some self-help books that said the best relationships have great communication. So, how was your day?

While we've got your attention, we wanted to tell you that your yearly Discord subscription will automatically renew on Jan 14, 2024! Unless you cancel between now and one day before that date, the payment method provided during registration will be charged $99.99 and your subscription will be extended for a year.

Great, got that communication out of the way. Now we'll go read that book on positive affirmations. "We're a good chat app. We're a really good chat app." Feeling better already.

Seeya next communication,

Discord

subject: Upcoming changes to your subscription
body:
Hi shaw,

We’re writing to let you know about an upcoming change to your Nitro subscription(s).

Starting on January 14, 2025, we'll begin charging applicable tax in addition to your current subscription payments for your Nitro subscription(s), which will renew at $99.99 plus $8.25.

As always, you can manage your subscription anytime on Discord under Settings>Subscriptions or directly through your Google Play or Apple iOS settings if you subscribed on a mobile device.

Thanks for being a subscriber!

Discord

subject: Fwd: [Final reminder] Google Podcasts Manager is going away
body:
Let's find a time to chat about this—submitting our RSS feed to YouTube...


---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Google Podcasts <podcasts-noreply@google.com>
Date: Thu, Jun 27, 2024 at 1:53 PM
Subject: [Final reminder] Google Podcasts Manager is going away
To: <ioastudios.content@gmail.com>


 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
[image: Google Podcasts Manager]

Hi Ifeoma,

‌

This a final reminder that Google Podcasts Manager is going away after
July 29, 2024. Until then, you will continue to have access to your
analytics in Google Podcasts Manager and can export them
<https://notifications.google.com/g/p/ANiao5qUzxpHAUZlyF_gFuNVBsvXRSiWu6lqQpGkXXkC-pFeuhwXLdbkFz7dzIZ-v_W6T9wLbT2FjQ3fI5OlroIBAOQCOj-o4JE7oh5ZE0CYtdMmrldOzMHNdTct2uH-GAHabiYsfN09Twqo8TgcmHtfsHVG5lRERm6hpVOErzTfzrJkVGc7VFjB22jYDA8kJXCG-vX0Jozo5tEkwgvYyGS5_bai8CTOc5oBdiY1wIzsCnIBOlq9yUACOQ4TMSlT4Z7ynGG0hvMipXe-K9RRLTaP>
if you wish.

‌

If you would like to bring your podcast to YouTube, you can submit your
podcast’s RSS feed. If you submit your RSS feed to YouTube, all new
episodes added to your RSS feed will automatically be uploaded to YouTube
and will also be made available on YouTube Music. Alternatively, you
can upload your
video podcast
<https://notifications.google.com/g/p/ANiao5rCiNPDN0JW_T7wuUkIYjfLvMl-OYrtH7teZeLhBXV5370TcEmHbE0tfewngC6h8s-Q1QT5_szkqH6XVj9FPLRw0bsy1WSLati1MDYFohACkDOmruwvMKanR3runN24mhS1pJ8QDAH42xQ1uBX3Fc68AaZ5SnAhpRVil9tD73HaNXQ8vF-uT21knpCRJ3yEyO1g2Fm2aIRBENIxTnuPHkSNU0swuGY-1leCIRadtj5QBRJ4J9_B0ThEfGjeIzjNfMZE1oBowjgKicnJszz41x7Qma-Xn8TWn1IuZjJ8hUIAqfgN3ZhphiaOrpJX219nOY2Boz3nASHZRmw>
in YouTube Studio.

‌

The easiest way to submit your RSS feed to YouTube is to visit your
Google Podcasts
Manager dashboard
<https://notifications.google.com/g/p/ANiao5rm4xgnhSKHJdwD9kVRd0nBAd1yu-Ph3TJgHBalTBzmRMrPStVA7uDe0Yu6-nGcM7j-Hu_ejvl2VvLw5UcuXdopIhJC14JkMsgCCx7DJt5__ln2U91Ey_oMwr2nSda3HjEzV2rzGXxaX90aVWrEtrj-mjMefnv0Cns78e1gsw-fStDNhwG2x0Yj9GlLVUsTezbjlMqrE8QlUOlQY57hxfWzctNk_os5WCTwCvZmzp8rz6sPJQ>,
find the banner at the top, and select Submit to YouTube.

‌

Thank you,
The Google Podcasts Manager team



You received this mandatory email service announcement to update you about
important changes to your Google Podcasts Manager product or account.

subject: Get excited, your REMO experience is starting soon!
body:
REMO Workspaces Reminder
 

Dear Shawhin Talebi,

Get ready for the best work-life balance experience you ever had! We can’t wait to welcome you at REMO Workspaces. Here we listed your booking summary, the check in process, WiFi connection details, food delivery information and additional links for help in case you need it. Enjoy REMO

Reservation Details

Check-in

Saturday 24 August 2024

Check-out

Saturday 24 August 2024

Your reservation

1 day

Location

501 Twin Creeks Dr, Twin Creeks, TX 75013, United States

REMO Workspaces are located outdoors, within Twin Creeks Golf Course facility. To find REMO Workspaces simply head towards the Golf Range. On the left, behind the Club House you will see the REMO Workspaces.

Workspace Module Details

Check-in

Saturday 24 August 2024 12:00 AM (сleaning hours: from 6:00 AM to 8:00 AM)

Check-out

Saturday 24 August 2024 11:59 PM

REMO module number

W4

WiFi Name

RemoW4

WiFi Password

LevelUp4

Payment Details

Total Amount

$0.00

Booking ID

646

View booking

CHECK-IN GUIDELINES
 
  1. At the arrival please provide The Golf Club at Twin Creeks front desk staff with your booking confirmation.
  2. Make sure your phone is connected to the internet.
  3. Utilize the unlock feature for your work-module via the REMO web site https://remo.club.
    • Click “Log In” button on the website
    • “Sign In” through your email address or through your LinkedIn / Google account.
    • Inside your Remo Workspaces account see your active bookings and click the “Unlock” button that will enable you to open the door.
    • You are all set.

  4. To lock the door, press the 'Lock' button in your active bookings on your Remo Workspace account or press and hold the # button on the external part of the door handle.

  5. You can order food and beverages at the bar located inside the Golf Club House.

  6. The restroom is located on the Golf Club House premises.

The Golf Club at Twin Creeks

 

501 Twin Creeks Dr

Twin Creeks

TX 75013

 

Need some extra help?

Contact us directly or through our website https://remo.club

View The Golf Club at Twin Creeks Support Page. Please note the operating hours of The Golf Club at Twin Creeks. Operating hours on holidays may vary.

Cancellation policy: REMO customers can cancel their upcoming reservations up to 24 hours prior to the reservation date.

 

In order to cancel your booking, please email support@remo.club with your name, date of bookings, and your reason for cancellation.

 

For more information and news about the upcoming Remo locations, follow us on LinkedIn, Instagram, or Facebook

subject: Thanks for joining the Medium Partner Program
body:
Thanks for joining the Medium Partner Program
Start Writing
Now that you've connected your payment information, you're ready to start writing. Just set each story to be eligible to earn money when you're ready to publish, and you'll earn based on the engagement your stories receive from paying members. Your writing will still reach everyone: Our metered paywall gives non-members a select number of free stories each  month, and you'll receive a Friend Link for every story you publish, which gives free story access to anyone who clicks it.
Write a story: https://medium.com/new-story?source=email-f3998e1cd186--payment.welcome

Be part of the community
We're building Medium to be a better place to share your ideas on the internet, so we've set some guidelines for what's permitted in your Partner Program stories to create a fair environment for writers and a richer reading experience for members.
Review the guidelines: https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/360006362473

Track your earnings
Your Partner Program earnings dashboard will display the payment history and current earnings for the stories you've made eligible to earn money. Each month, when we send payment, we'll email you. For more data on your earnings, you can visit each of your stories' individual stats pages.
View your Partner Program earnings: https://medium.com/me/partner/dashboard?source=email-f3998e1cd186--payment.welcome

Save yourself some time
Now that you're in the Medium Partner Program, please take a minute to submit your taxpayer information. This is required for all Medium Partner Program writers, regardless of citizenship or country of residence.
Add taxpayer infomation: https://medium.com/me/partner/taxes

For details, review our Taxes FAQ (https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/sections/360001924873-Taxes)
---
Sent by Medium, P.O. Box 602, San Francisco, CA 94104-0602
To unsubscribe, visit https://medium.com/me/email-settings/f3998e1cd186/cf376a80a461?source=email-f3998e1cd186--payment.welcome&type=required

subject: You’ve published your first Partner Program story. What’s next?
body:
You've published a story as part of the Medium Partner Program: The Wavelet Transform (https://medium.com/p/the-wavelet-transform-e9cfa85d7b34?source=email-f3998e1cd186--payment.schedule)
.

Your story is eligible to earn money and to be shown as part of the metered paywall. If our curators recommend your story to readers by adding it to relevant topics, we will email you to let you know.
Share your story
Get the word out about your story by sharing it with friends and fans. With our metered paywall, readers can access a select number of stories per month for free - so everyone can read and share your story, not just members. Plus, we give you a Friend Link (https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/360006543813)
 for every story you publish through the Medium Partner Program. The Friend Link gives free story access to anyone who clicks it, while ensuring you still earn when members read and engage. Share on Facebook  Share on Twitter

Check your stats
See your engagement metrics and know where your views are coming from. When your audience grows, you'll be able to see what topics your readers are interested in to help you write your next story.
View your story's stats: https://medium.com/me/stats/post/e9cfa85d7b34?source=email-f3998e1cd186--payment.schedule

See what you've earned
Your story's earnings will be updated every day on your story's stats page. We will send your earnings for each calendar month by the 8th of the following month.
View your Partner Program earnings: https://medium.com/me/partner/dashboard?source=email-f3998e1cd186--payment.schedule

Pro tip: Share your writing. You earn when Medium members read your stories, as well as when someone reads your story and then subscribes to Medium.
Ready to write another piece? Our members and curators love reading thoughtful, insightful pieces on a wide range of topics. Check out our Curation Guidelines (https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/360006362473-Medium-s-Curation-Guidelines-Everything-Writers-Need-to-Know)
 to give your next stories the best chance to find an audience and earn money on Medium.
Write another story: https://medium.com/new-story?source=email-f3998e1cd186--payment.schedule
---
Sent by Medium, P.O. Box 602, San Francisco, CA 94104-0602
To unsubscribe, visit https://medium.com/me/email-settings/f3998e1cd186/e3f8985afd4e?source=email-f3998e1cd186--payment.schedule&type=required

subject: We’re evolving the Partner Program and have updated our Terms
body:
Medium ( https://medium.com/ )

( https://blog.medium.com/evolving-the-partner-program-2613708f9f3c )

Before diving into the announcements below, please note that we have updated the Medium Partner Program Terms. They cover the changes described in this email: the new Referred Membership opportunities and new criteria for participation in the Partner Program. These changes may affect your payout.

Please review the updated Medium Partner Program Terms ( https://policy.medium.com/medium-partner-program-terms-fcfe9cf777b8 ) for full details -- your continued participation in the Partner Program signals your agreement to be bound by them.

And now, on to the announcements.

Now there are even more ways to earn money on Medium. Introducing Referred Memberships, where Partner Program writers (that’s you!) can refer dedicated readers to become Medium members.

Here’s how it works ( https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/4405927192215-Referred-memberships ) : Every time you convert a reader to a paying member, you get half of that reader’s membership fee, net of standard payment processor fees, for as long as they are an active member. Referral earnings are additional to existing Partner Program earnings, which are based on member read time. Readers can sign up on your personalized referrals page.

( https://blog.medium.com/evolving-the-partner-program-2613708f9f3c )

Also, when a non-members subscribes to receive your stories by email ( https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us/articles/360059837393-Email-subscriptions ) , they'll be given the option to convert to a Medium member. If they sign up for a Medium membership at that time, it will count toward your referral earnings.

( https://blog.medium.com/evolving-the-partner-program-2613708f9f3c )

You can track the number of referred memberships you've driven and retained by clicking “Audience stats” on the top right of your stats dashboard on desktop or mobile web ( https://medium.com/me/stats ). For more details on Referred Memberships, including an example of how earnings are calculated, read our blog post. ( https://medium.com/@MediumStaff/2613708f9f3c )

( https://blog.medium.com/evolving-the-partner-program-2613708f9f3c )

*Start promoting your page by going to the Audience Development section of your Settings, then clicking Promote memberships ( https://medium.com/me/settings ) from desktop or mobile web.*

( https://medium.com/me/settings )

*New Partner Program eligibility criteria*

We have added a simple application process ( https://mediumpartnerprogram.typeform.com/apply ) , to joining the Partner Program, a common practice on most platforms, that requires writers to meet some basic criteria. New Partner Program writers must have at least 100 followers and have published at least one story in order to apply. As a current Partner Program writer, *you are automatically enrolled through the end of the year* and do not need to apply at this time, though you will need to meet the same criteria by the end of 2021.

Last, going forward all Partner Program writers need to stay active to remain in the program. We may disable monetization for writers who haven't been active for 6 months. We'll send a notification before we take any action and share resources to help you get back on track.

----------------------------
Read or write from anywhere.
----------------------------

( https://apps.apple.com/app/medium-everyones-stories/id828256236 ) ( https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.medium.reader )

Sent by Medium ( https://medium.com/ ) · P.O. Box 602, San Francisco, CA 94104-0602
You have received this notice about the Partner Program Terms because you are enrolled in Medium's Partner Program.
Help center ( https://help.medium.com/hc/en-us ) · Privacy policy ( https://medium.com/policy/f03bf92035c9 )

( https://medium-a7e301761373.intercom-mail.com/subscriptions/unsubscribe?app_id=zp3ii0g5&sample=true )

subject: The Value Heuristic
body:
Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1643205770680-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------6c1e7685_080f_4f12_a285_b22bee917b38--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ·  4 min read  ·  View on Medium (https://medium.com/p/the-value-heuristic-31151d7eacdc?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1643205770680-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------6c1e7685_080f_4f12_a285_b22bee917b38--------3ec6dd6333f3)

The Value Heuristic
Why you are leaving value on the table
Decisions are a key part of everyday life. Should I do this instead of that? What do I stand to gain from this? Is this worth my time? Although they are common, decisions require effort. That is why our brains have a few shortcuts for making them. These shortcuts are called heuristics. While they work most of the time, there are situations in which they fail. Here I'll discuss one such failure I call the value heuristic. It explains why people overvalue money and tend to leave value on the table.
What can happen when you take shortcuts. Image from here [3].
The Heuristic
When you hear the word "value", what is the first thing that comes to mind?
For many, it's money. Money has value. And it's value is clear cut. $1 can get me a cheeseburger, $10 can get me a book, $100 can get me a new pair of Nikes.
Now, imagine you are asked a slightly different and more difficult question like: what has the most value?
Typically, when asked difficult questions our brains automatically replace it for an easier question. This is what Daniel Kahnaman and Amos Tversky called a substitution [1]. This is a specific type of heuristic (mental shortcut) that we all use.
Many heuristics exist. Most are silly and inconsequential. Like, thinking a woman who is outspoken and bright is less likely to be a bank teller, than both a bank teller and an activist [2 (http://me.dm/r-Pz1_AKRNZR?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1643205770680-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------6c1e7685_080f_4f12_a285_b22bee917b38--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. However, the one I am highlighting here causes unnecessary suffering.
The value heuristic, as I will call it, is substituting the hard question of "what has the most value?", with an easier question like, "what has value?" Using a substitution heuristic, the answer to the first question will be the same as the second, which for many is money.
This causes people to automatically (i.e. unconsciously) give too much weight to money in decision making. For example, valuing a well paying job that one doesn't enjoy so much, over a lower paying job one might enjoy more.
What's more valuable than money?
It's easy to brush off the notion that there are things more valuable than money. "Yeah, yeah I get it. There's more to life than money, but I still want it". Don't get me wrong, money isn't negligible. Money may not buy happiness, but poverty does bring misery.
My point is simply, people often give too much weight to money when making decisions. To highlight the point, consider the following: health, time, energy, relationships, freedom, etc. Most people will agree that these things have value. Many may also agree that these things have more value than money. Yet, value judgements are often driven by, you guessed it.. money. While these other things are often secondary.
The Most Valuable Thing
So what is the answer to this difficult question: what has the most value? Well, it depends on your values. Some will say time, some will say energy, some may still say money even after thinking about it. I would say it differently.
The most valuable thing (I believe) is people. Spending time with people you like, undertaking projects with a team, sharing experiences with others.
Regardless of your answer, don't use a heuristic to get to it. Stop and think about it, so you can truly get the most value out of life.
Note on Value Dynamics
The story of value (as I see it) is a bit more complicated than what I've presented. The reality is, value changes over time. In other words, value is dynamic.
The change of values is based on a simple principle. The more available something is, the less valuable it becomes. Money is cheap to the rich. Time is cheap to the young. Energy is cheap to the active.
When making value judgements we may need to consider this interdependent web of value. When you really stop and think about this, it's no wonder why our brains prefer heuristics. Value judgements are hard.
Conclusion
The value heuristic is when we (unconsciously) replace the hard question of "what has the most value?", with an easy question "what has value?" Although it saves mental effort, it often leads to overvaluing money and ultimately leaving value on the table. Stop and think about this hard question, so when value decisions come up, you can make better choices and get the most value out of life.
Resources
[1] Thinking, Fast and Slow by Daniel Kahneman (http://me.dm/r-5ZIj-az6aX?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1643205770680-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------6c1e7685_080f_4f12_a285_b22bee917b38--------3ec6dd6333f3)

[2] Linda Problem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjunction_fallacy
[3] http://theflyingtortoise.blogspot.com/2015/09/there-is-no-shortcut-on-road-to-success.html
-
Last blog - Multikills: How to Do More With Less (https://medium.com/simple-success/multikills-how-to-do-more-with-less-bb107fa86951)

Instagram| YouTube | My website |Pinterest| Twitter

Reply to this story: mailto:shawhintalebi@gmail.com?subject=Re: The%20Value%20Heuristic

View story: https://medium.com/p/the-value-heuristic-31151d7eacdc?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1643205770680-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------6c1e7685_080f_4f12_a285_b22bee917b38--------3ec6dd6333f3
---
Sent by Medium, P.O. Box 602, San Francisco, CA 94104-0602
To unsubscribe, visit https://medium.com/me/email-settings/f3998e1cd186/8f21f498a573?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1643205770680-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------6c1e7685_080f_4f12_a285_b22bee917b38--------3ec6dd6333f3&type=required&newsletterId=76094f821b6e&newsletterV3Id=3ec6dd6333f3

subject: Your Medium membership is about to renew
body:
Hi there,

You're an annual Medium member, which means you're getting unlimited, year-round access to some of the best writing out there, by some of the sharpest thinkers on the globe. And at $50 a year, you're saving $10 compared to our monthly membership option. (That's two to eight coffees, depending on your feelings about coffee.)

Rest easy - your membership automatically renews for another year on July 25, 2022 for $50 on the credit card we have on file. No clicks required.

If you'd like to update your credit card information, go to your Medium Settings page (https://medium.com/me/settings?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1657564046463-membership.annualRenewalReminder-------------------------004ac8bc_32ad_4533_a74e_c07688b147f4#credit-card)
 under 'Payment info'. No charge will be made to your card until the renewal date. To switch to a monthly subscription, reply to this email.

subject: Your Medium membership is about to renew
body:

You're an annual Medium member, which means you're getting unlimited, year-round access to some of the best writing out there, by some of the sharpest thinkers on the globe. And at $50 a year, you're saving $10 compared to our monthly membership option. (That's two to eight coffees, depending on your feelings about coffee.)

subject: Causal Effects via the Do-operator
body:
Translating observations into interventions

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
8 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/p/5415aefc834a?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)

Causal Effects via the Do-operator
Translating observations into interventions
This is the 3rd article in a series on causal effects (http://me.dm/r-CuQuIiSLqE?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
. In the last post (http://me.dm/r-L4vVBwGViZ?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
, we reviewed a set of practical approaches for estimating effects via Propensity Scores. The downside of these approaches, however, is they do not account for unmeasured confounders. By the end of this article we will see how we can overcome this shortcoming. But first, we need to take a step back and reevaluate how we think about causal effects.
Key Points:
The do-operator is a mathematical representation of an intervention
An intervention is the intentional manipulation of a data generating process
Using Pearl's Structural Causal Framework we can estimate the effect of interventions using observational data

Translating observational data into interventional data. Image by author.
···
Up to this point in the series, we have (for the most part) taken a classic statistical approach to the computation of causal effects. In other words, we split our data into two populations (e.g. treatment and control group) and compared their means. However, there is a more robust way to think about things.
Master of Causality Judea Pearl frames things in what he calls a Structural approach to causality [1 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. A central piece of this approach is the so-called do-operator.
We first saw the do-operator in the article on causal inference (http://me.dm/r-CuQuIiSLqE?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
. There, the operator was introduced as a mathematical representation of an intervention which enables us to compute causal effects. Here we will explore this notion in greater detail.
Average Treatment Effect with the Do-Operator
In the first post  (http://me.dm/r-CuQuIiSLqE?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
of this series, we defined the Average Treatment Effect (ATE) for a randomized controlled trial, as the difference in expected outcomes between two levels of treatment. In other words, we compare the expectation value of the outcome variable (e.g. has headache or not) conditioned on treatment status (e.g. took pill or not). This is one of the most widely used approaches to quantifying causal effects.

Formula 1: Average treatment effect for a randomized controlled trial [2]. Image by author.
Alternatively, ATE in Pearl's formulation is defined as the difference in expected outcomes between two levels of intervention [1 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. This is where the do-operator comes in.

Formula 2: Average treatment effect in terms of the do-operator [1]. Image by author.
Observational vs Interventional Distributions
The key difference between P(Y | X=x)) and P(Y | do(X=x)), is that the first specifics the probability of Y given a passive observation of X=x, while the latter represents the probability of Y given an intervention in X.
Here, I will call a distribution containing the do-operator an interventional distribution (e.g. P(Y | do(X=1))), while one without it, I will call an observational distribution. Note: this is similar to the distinction made in the last blog between observational and interventional studies.

Comparing observational distribution to interventional distribution. Image by author.
Formula 1 vs Formula 2
In the context of a Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT), Formula 1 and Formula 2 are equivalent. Since treatment assignments are intentionally (and carefully) manipulated by experimenters. However, once we move outside of an RCT (or something similar), Formula 1 is no longer valid, but Formula 2 is.
In this way, we can think of Formula 2 as a generalization of Formula 1. This new formulation provides us a clearer picture of causal effects. It helps move us away from ad hoc equations for specific contexts, to a more general (and powerful) framework. In the next section, we will see the power of this formulation in practice.
Identifiability
Connecting observational and interventional distributions in 3 steps
While theory and abstractions can be helpful, at some point we need to connect them to reality (i.e. our data). In the context of causality, this raises the question of identifiability. In other words, can the interventional distribution be obtained from the given data? [1 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]
As I alluded to earlier, if we have data from an interventional study (e.g. an RCT), we indeed have the interventional distribution (that's what we painstakingly measured). But what if we only have observational data?
Lucky for us, this problem has already been solved by Pearl and colleagues [1 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. The solution can be broken down into 3 steps.
Step 1 - Write down a causal model
Causal models were introduced in the previous series on causality (http://me.dm/r-im32Z6PCOi?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
. A simple causal model can be represented by something called a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG), which depicts the causal connections between variables via dots and arrows, where A → B represents A causes B.
We saw an example DAG in the last post (http://me.dm/r-L4vVBwGViZ?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 of this series which looked something like the image below. Notice we don't have (or need) the details of the connections (i.e. the functional relationships between variables), only what causes what.

Example DAG representing causal connections between age, grad school, and income. Image by author.
Step 2 - Evaluate the Markov Condition
Once we have a DAG in hand, we can evaluate a condition that guarantees identifiability. This is called the Markov Condition, and if satisfied, causal effects are identifiable. Meaning we can compute Formula 2 from observational data (no RCT needed!).
The Markov Condition has 2-parts. One, the graph must be acyclic, which is true of all DAGs (that's what the "A" stands for). And two, all noise terms are jointly independent. What this 2nd point means is that there are no variables excluded from the DAG that simultaneously cause any 2 variables. Some examples of when this is satisfied/violated are given below.

Simple examples of when Markov condition is satisfied and violated. Image by author.
Step 3 - Translate observations into interventions
If we confirmed our DAG is Markovian (i.e. satisfies the Markov condition), we can express any interventional distribution via observational ones using the Truncated Factorization Formula given below.

Truncated factorization formula [1]. Image by author.
To isolate treatment and outcome variables on the LHS distribution, we can sum over the covariates (i.e. all the other variables). For example, in the simple DAG from the last blog (http://me.dm/r-L4vVBwGViZ?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
, the process would go as follows.

Simple example of expressing interventional distribution P(Y|do(x0)) in terms of observational data via the truncated factorization formula. Image by author.
As we can see from the example above, for the given DAG we must adjust for the covariate Z. This is what we did (intuitively) back in the post on causal inference (http://me.dm/r-_U04_PWUsN?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
. However, here we derived this result from the truncated factorization formula, rather than relying on intuition.
This 3-step process gives us systematic way to calculate causal effects from observational data. The key that enables us to do this is a causal model that satisfies the Markov condition. We can take this process a step further and use it to deal with the problem of unmeasured confounders.
Coping with Unmeasured Confounders
A problem in data collection is variables are sometimes difficult or even impossible to measure. This raises the issue of unmeasured confounders, meaning variables that bias our causal effect estimate which we do not have data for. Again lucky for us, this Structural Causal Framework has a solution for this problem.
We explore the problem of unmeasured confounders via an example (taken) from the introduction by Pearl [1 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. Suppose we have the following Markovian causal model.

More complicated Markovian causal model from [1]. Image by author.
Then, like we did before, we can write down the interventional distribution P(Y | do(X=x0)) via the Truncated Factorization Formula and summing over covariates. The algebra is given in the below image.

More complicated example of expressing the interventional distribution P(Y|do(x0)) in terms of observational data via the truncated factorization formula [1]. Image by author.
But now suppose Z_2 is hard (or impossible) to measure. How can we compute the estimation above with our data? This is indeed possible and the result is given below.

Coping with the unmeasured confounder Z_2 [1]. Image by author.
While this final step may have seemed like magic, it comes from the following equation.

Expression for an interventional distribution only adjusting for the direct causes of X [1]. Image by author.
The key point here is we only need to measure the parents of X to estimate its causal effects. What makes this expression valid is the Markov condition, which requires that any variable (when conditioned on its parents) is independent of its non-descendent.
In other words, by conditioning on Z_1 and Z_3, we block that statistical dependence between X and Z_3. In next blog of this series, we will explore other possible reductions to the truncated factorization formula.
How to use this with Propensity Scores
Going back to the last article (http://me.dm/r-L4vVBwGViZ?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 of this series, we can use what we have learned here to improve our estimates of causal effects via Propensity Scores. To generate a propensity score, we take a set of subject characteristics (i.e. covariates) and use them to predict treatment status via, for example, logistic regression [2 (http://me.dm/r-gov7RFmj6l?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. However, choosing the right covariates is not a trivial step.
One way we can overcome this challenge is by including only the parents of X in the propensity score model. Therefore, if we take the time to write down a causal model for our problem, we can pick out the covariates in a straightforward way. For example, in the DAG above we would only include Z_1 and Z_3 in our propensity score model, even if Z_2 is measured.
Alternative Covariate Selection
While needing only to account for the direct causes of X is a powerful insight, what if the parents of X are unmeasured?
This motivates seeking alternative covariates with which to express our interventional distribution. In the next post of this series will do exactly this and discuss causal effects via graphical models.
···
Resources
More on Causality: Causality: Intro (http://me.dm/r-im32Z6PCOi?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 | Causal Inference (http://me.dm/r-_U04_PWUsN?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 | Causal Discovery (http://me.dm/r-cD0J2s5mG5?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 | Causal Effects (http://me.dm/r-CuQuIiSLqE?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 | Propensity Score (http://me.dm/r-YOlyM-UAZW?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)

···
[1] An Introduction to Causal Inference (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1664372501801-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------d69269c8_13fa_46e7_bad1_b4e313c7e7f9--------3ec6dd6333f3)

subject: 5 Reasons Why Every Data Scientist Should Consider Freelancing
body:
It may be uncomfortable, but it's good for you

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667278556808-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------f7ff2380_e449_4c0d_94ac_531c12681eae--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 in Towards Data Science (https://medium.com/towards-data-science?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667278556808-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------f7ff2380_e449_4c0d_94ac_531c12681eae--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
4 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/42ad24fad3e?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667278556808-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------f7ff2380_e449_4c0d_94ac_531c12681eae--------3ec6dd6333f3)

5 Reasons Why Every Data Scientist Should Consider Freelancing
It may be uncomfortable, but it's good for you

Photo by Andrew Neel on Unsplash
Whether you are employed or unemployed, a seasoned pro or a novice, like it or not, freelancing can be good for you.
Before diving into it, a little background on me. I started working in data science during grad school. For those who aren't familiar, the bulk of grad school consists of research, deadlines, and writing a thesis.
Halfway through my 3rd year, I started my freelancing journey by taking on short-term projects and fusing them into my research and writing schedules. While I would have learned plenty without this additional workload, freelancing took my development as a data scientist to another level. Here I will discuss 5 benefits I have found through my experience.
···
1) Work on New Problems
One of the greatest powers of data science is that it is context agnostic. Meaning you can use the same technique to solve a wide range of problems (e.g. logistic regression - assessing customer churn, evaluating credit risk, predicting stock prices, etc). This gives data scientists a unique opportunity to apply their expertise to a wide range of fields and industries.
Despite this opportunity, it's easy for data scientists to operate in a narrow set of contexts, which can be problematic if your goal is to learn and improve.
This brings up the first benefit I found in freelancing: exposure to new fields and problems. It feels similar to traveling. Just as visiting abroad helps you gain a greater understanding of life and culture, exploring new problems helps you gain a deeper understanding of data science.
2) Improve Communication via Marketing, Interviewing, Negotiation, etc.
Data scientists aren't typically known for their supreme powers of sales, marketing, and negotiation. This is exactly why freelancing was good for me. It provided me with several opportunities to develop these skills.
When you freelance, most potential clients are strangers. Therefore you need to connect and communicate with people who don't know anything about what you know or how you can solve their problems. In other words, you need to sell yourself and your ideas, which is a good skill set to have no matter where you end up in life.
3) Fine-tune Pitches Through Iterations
There are 2 key elements to learning: reps and feedback. The more reps and the faster the feedback the better. Accordingly, if you're trying to improve your resume, craft compelling proposals, or present yourself effectively, you need reps and feedback.
This is an aspect in which freelancing dominates full-time roles. There are significantly more contract opportunities out there than full-time roles. Furthermore, contract roles operate on much shorter time scales.
Put explicitly,
More contract opportunities mean more reps.
Shorter timescales mean faster feedback.

Needless to say, the contractor is going to have a much better pitch than the full-timer.
4) Flexibility & Autonomy
Another aspect in which freelance dominates (most) full-time roles is flexibility. Contracts often don't restrict when or where work needs to be done, it just needs to get done by the deadline. If that means you work 4 hours a day from a loft in Honduras or 12 hours Monday-Wednesday from your mom's basement, you are free to do that.
Additionally, you choose your work. If a project seems boring, no need to pursue it. Conversely, if a project looks exciting you have a big influence on your chances of getting that contract.
This tremendous autonomy doesn't just sound like the good life, it has a big impact on motivation. When we can choose what we work on, when we work on it, and who we work with, the work we do is more engaging.
5) Build Relationships & New Connections
The final benefit I have found in freelancing is developing new relationships. There is a saying that "your network is your net worth". The way I interpret this is, who you know has value.
Sure, you can put a dollar amount to it, but often the value comes through as meaningful connections, engaging conversations, and the comfort of "having a guy (or gal) for that".
Through my contract work, I have had the opportunity to meet fascinating people who work in worlds I didn't even know existed. I've worked with ER doctors, special forces operators, clinicians, business people, and researchers with so many different backgrounds and experiences. These connections have truly enriched how I see the world.
Bonus: Money 🤑
If these 5 reasons weren't enough, there is always the money. Data science contracting work can be very lucrative. Typical hourly rates are around $56 an hour according to ZipRecruiter (http://me.dm/r-RkU3jgJoDs?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667278556808-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------f7ff2380_e449_4c0d_94ac_531c12681eae--------3ec6dd6333f3)
, while Interview Query (http://me.dm/r-ry4nfgee2f?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667278556808-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------f7ff2380_e449_4c0d_94ac_531c12681eae--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 states even higher rates above $200. Whether it is the main source of income or just a side gig, freelancing is a good way to bring in cash.
···
Resources
More on Data Science: What is data science? (http://me.dm/r-QqD03oNfpb?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667278556808-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------f7ff2380_e449_4c0d_94ac_531c12681eae--------3ec6dd6333f3)

subject: What is a Data Entrepreneur?
body:
And what is left on the table without them

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667658949350-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------7068f763_7124_42be_9c01_2f68af2532a7--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 in The Data Entrepreneurs (https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667658949350-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------7068f763_7124_42be_9c01_2f68af2532a7--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
4 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs/ae0470bdac7b?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667658949350-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------7068f763_7124_42be_9c01_2f68af2532a7--------3ec6dd6333f3)

What is a Data Entrepreneur?
And what is left on the table without them

A Venn diagram of data entrepreneurs. Image by the author.
···
There is no shortage of hype around data and its role in our future. As a result, it seems that all the cool jobs these days are required to include the word data, e.g. data scientist, data analyst, data engineer, etc. However, there is a data "job title" that sits apart from the rest, data entrepreneur.
At first glance, we may think context distinguishes the data entrepreneur from the rest. The former roles operate in large organizations, while the latter might be on their own or in a small team. This may be typical, but I'd say some data entrepreneurs operate in the largest corporations, and some data analysts in small businesses.
Next, we might say the difference is an appetite for risk. Data entrepreneurs are risk-takers chasing a big exit. While I don't doubt this view drives many, they likely have a short life as an entrepreneur.
A friend of Elon Musk once said, "Starting a company is like eating glass and staring into the abyss." Accordingly, one often needs more than just thrill and money to persevere through the constant adversity and uncertainty that comes with entrepreneurship.
So if not context or risk, what distinguishes the data entrepreneur? I'd say it is a drive to explore new possibilities rather than exploit known solutions.
Sure, the stereotype of a solo risk-taker might fit the bill, but there is much more variation than that. A data entrepreneur could be a salaried data engineer pushing for new initiatives at a large tech company; she could be a content creator with a passion for helping people grasp data science concepts or even a researcher who leverages emerging data technologies to drive scientific discovery.
More concisely, a data entrepreneur is a person who pursues data-centered ventures using the skillset of a data practitioner with the mindset of an entrepreneur.
The Problem - We're all living the dream
The three most harmful addictions are heroin, carbohydrates, and a monthly salary - Nassim Nicholas Taleb
One thing that makes all these data jobs appealing is that companies pay a pretty penny to attract and keep talent. This might sound good initially, but this is a big problem if we want to maximize our collective potential.
We, i.e. human beings, are very bad at doing uncomfortable things when we don't have to. Going for a run might be hard, but if a family of snakes appeared by your feet, you'd run right out the door. This (silly) example highlights a key feature of human behavior and motivation.
We are very good at doing uncomfortable, hard, and even impossible things when it is demanded by our environment and situation.
This is the problem with the current norm. Many data practitioners have well-paying and comfortable gigs where they aren't (typically) forced to push beyond themselves to grow, adapt, and get better continually.
The Opportunity - Value & Vacuum
There is a reason data roles get paid the big bucks. The work provides tremendous value to the employer. Herein lies the first opportunity for the data entrepreneur. The skillset of the data entrepreneur is valuable.
While there are many others with this skillset (e.g. data scientists, data engineers, etc), far fewer have the mindset of an entrepreneur. This brings up the second opportunity. The ubiquity of well-paved and clearly defined data opportunities naturally leaves all the lesser-known and ambiguous options on the table. In other words, there is a massive vacuum in the space of opportunities that data entrepreneurs can exploit.
How Do I Become a Data Entrepreneur?
For the data practitioner, the path to data entrepreneurship is simple. Move toward discomfort. More specifically, this might be any of the following actions:
Carve out an hour a day for independent research or development
Connect with other data entrepreneurs and learn from each other (my door is always open 😁)
Identify a problem that would bring you great pain if never solved then pursue it
Create content based on your data expertise and share it online
Pick-up data contract work on platforms like Upwork or Fiverr
Set aside time to work on interesting projects

···
Resources
More on Data Science: What is data science? (http://me.dm/r-QqD03oNfpb?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1667658949350-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------7068f763_7124_42be_9c01_2f68af2532a7--------3ec6dd6333f3)
