subject: How to Start Freelancing in Data Science
body:
A 5-step quick-start guide for everyone

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1668271040507-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------e9322fcf_e30d_47b7_a3cc_2a7262deff59--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 in The Data Entrepreneurs (https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1668271040507-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------e9322fcf_e30d_47b7_a3cc_2a7262deff59--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
4 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs/150551f25fda?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1668271040507-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------e9322fcf_e30d_47b7_a3cc_2a7262deff59--------3ec6dd6333f3)

How to Start Freelancing in Data Science
A 5-step quick-start guide for everyone

Photo by David Gavi on Unsplash
Whether its immediately or 9 months later (like me), if you do the obvious things long enough, you will be successful
···
In a recent article, I highlighted 5 reasons why every data scientist should consider freelancing (http://me.dm/r-Ff-x2X0fnI?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1668271040507-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------e9322fcf_e30d_47b7_a3cc_2a7262deff59--------3ec6dd6333f3)
. For many, however, freelancing is unexplored territory, making it difficult to know exactly where to start. To help these aspiring data science freelancers, here I share the step-by-step strategy I used to get started.
I began my freelancing journey while doing grad school full-time. Naturally, there were a lot of reasons why I should not have pursued freelancing. A big one was the obvious time constraint. I was working on a Ph.D. and had more than enough work juggling research projects. But the even bigger obstacle was self-doubt.
What if I'm not good enough to freelance? In retrospect, I can confidently say that the space is so massive and diverse that almost anyone can find work as a freelancer; it doesn't matter if you have a high school diploma or a Ph.D.
But of course, I didn't have this confidence at the time. So, to combat the lack of confidence, my main strategy was to start small. I would set hilariously easy goals for myself. For example, make an Upwork profile. Or look at jobs for 15 min today. Or apply to just 1 job this week. Following this strategy and incrementally increasing my targets, I eventually got to the point of consistently applying to 1–3 jobs every week.
···
A 5-step Algorithm
Now for a little more detail. The strategy I used to get into freelancing can be broken down into a simple 5 step algorithm (listed below). If this strategy seems ridiculously obvious, that is because it is.
Most roads to success are obvious; the problem is either 1) people don't bother trying or 2) they give up way too early. But I promise you, if you pursue it long enough and do the obvious things, you will be successful.
1) Pick a platform
The freelancing space has seemed to explode since 2020. Consequently, there are several platforms to choose from for getting contract work. The one that I have the most experience with is Upwork. On Upwork, clients post jobs they need to be done, and contractors submit proposals outlining their bid price and why they are a good fit for the role.
2) Make an account (it's literally 2 clicks)
Once I identified the platform (Upwork), the next obvious step was to make a profile. This was very straightforward. I went to Upwork's website, hit "Sign Up," and then signed up with my Google account. Literally 2 clicks. From there, I essentially made my Upwork profile a carbon copy of my LinkedIn page.
While it's easy enough to make an Upwork profile, it probably took me 6 months to go from first thinking about freelancing and actually creating an account (talk about starting small 😅).
3) Review postings
Next, I would review job listings. More specifically, anything related to data science or programming. This step surprised me because developing a good eye for which jobs best match your skills and goals is a key part of the process. The best way I know how to develop this intuition is through reps and feedback, which brings us to the next step.
4) Apply for jobs
Once I targeted jobs that seemed like a good fit, the next step was to apply to them. I (again) spent longer than necessary to do this step. It was probably 1–2 months between when I created my Upwork account and finally applied for my first job 😬.
As far as applying for jobs goes, here are some tips I followed:
Go after verified payments (usually more serious clients)
Apply to new postings or postings with less than 5 submitted proposals or both (ideally)
Look for jobs that directly overlap with prior experience (e.g. a field you've worked in, a tool you've used, an application you are proficient with, etc.)
Repurpose successful proposals and rework unsuccessful ones
Link an example project directly related to the job posting (all the contracts I got had this)
Link your online portfolio at the end (make a portfolio if you don't have one)
Apply on a schedule. I did 1–3 proposals a week (when looking), but this depends on your current workload and goals.

5) Learn from feedback, then repeat step 3
The final step is critical if you want to accelerate your progress. Every proposal you submit is an opportunity for feedback, whether a yes, no, or no response. Learn what went right for the yeses and compare that to the noes and no responses. Take that feedback and start the loop over again. Develop your eye for good fits in step 3, and fine-tune your proposals in step 4.
···

subject: Causal Effects via DAGs
body:
Two graphical criteria for estimating causal effects

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 in Towards Data Science (https://medium.com/towards-data-science?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
9 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/801df31da794?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)

Causal Effects via DAGs
Two graphical criteria for estimating causal effects
This is the 4th article in a series on causal effects (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/causal-effects-f30f962ffff3)
. In the last article (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/causal-effects-via-the-do-operator-5415aefc834a)
 of this series, we explored the question of identifiability. In other words, can the causal effect be evaluated from the given data? There we saw a systematic 3-step process to express any causal effect given a causal model where all variables are observed. The problem, however, becomes much more interesting when we have unmeasured confounders. In this article, I discuss two quick-and-easy graphical criteria for evaluating causal effects.
https://medium.com/media/8b7e5e1fc0eb1fe05c19c2c0a7b528a5/href
···
Identifiability
Identifiability is a central question in causal analysis i.e. can the causal effect be evaluated from the given data? In the previous blog (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/causal-effects-via-the-do-operator-5415aefc834a)
, we saw a systematic 3-step process for answering this question for so-called Markovian causal models. These causal models satisfy two conditions: 1) no cycles and 2) no unmeasured noise terms that simultaneously cause two or more variables. This type of model can be represented by a directed cyclic graph i.e. a DAG. Examples of Markovian and non-Markovian DAGs are shown below.

Simple examples of non-Markovian and Markovian DAGs. Image by author.
The Markov condition is important because it guarantees identifiability. In other words, if our causal model is Markovian, then the causal effect is always identifiable [1 (http://me.dm/r-PUa8n7MNN9?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
, 2 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. While this is a powerful insight, it is also restrictive because we may be interested in causal models that are not Markovian.
For example, a Markovian model could become non-Markovian if there is an unmeasured confounder. We saw an example of this in the previous blog (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/causal-effects-via-the-do-operator-5415aefc834a)
. The same example is shown in the figure below.

Example of how a Markovian model can become non-Markovian. Image by author.
We start with the Markovian model on the far left. Then suppose Jimmy forgot to turn on the Z2 sensor, so we have no observations for the variable Z2. This situation is depicted by the model in the middle. Here we have an unobserved variable (Z2) with two children (Z3 and Y).
We can equivalently represent this situation by removing the unobserved variable from the DAG and connecting its two child nodes with a bi-directed edge [1 (http://me.dm/r-PUa8n7MNN9?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. Intuitively, the bi-directed edge represents the statistical dependence between Z3 and Y via Z2, but without observations of Z2, this will appear as a spurious association between the two in our data.
Note that the two right-most causal models are not Markovian. The middle one has an unmeasured noise term that simultaneously causes two variables, and the far right one has a cycle. Although these models are not Markovian, the causal effect of X on Y is indeed identifiable (more on that later).
3 Rules of Do-Calculus
In the general case, the question of identifiability can always be answered using the Rules of Do-Calculus [3 (http://me.dm/r-jpDipto7eR?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
, 4 (http://me.dm/r-dBtBW_13gT?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. These are 3 rules we can use to manipulate interventional distributions-in other words, expressing probabilities that include the do-operator in terms of probabilities that do not include the do-operator.
A key point is that this set of rules is complete, which means that if identifiability cannot be established with these 3 rules, then the causal effect is not identifiable.
Rules of Do-Calculus - Given X, Y, Z, and W are arbitrary disjoint sets of variables in a causal model G, the Rules of Do-Calculus are given below.

3 Rules of Do-Calculus [4]. Image by author.
Although these rules are concise and complete, there is a lot to chew on here. For example, looking at rule 1, we can ignore the set of variables W only if Y and Z are conditionally independent in the graph obtained by deleting all the incoming arrows to the nodes in X.
Without a strong intuition for these rules and associated concepts, applying them to problems can be slow and challenging. That is where two quick and easy tests for identifiability can help.
2 Quick-and-Easy Graphical Criteria
While the Rules of Do-Calculus give us a complete set of operations for evaluating causal effects, using them in practice can be difficult for complicated DAGs. To help with this difficulty, we can turn to 2 practical graphical criteria for evaluating identifiability: the Back Door Criterion (BDC) and the Front Door Criterion (FDC).
Unlike the rules of do-calculus, these criteria are not complete. Meaning even if they are not satisfied, the causal effect may still be identifiable. Their key utility, however, is they serve as practical tests we can readily apply to answer causal questions before resorting to the Rules of Do-Calculus.
1) Back Door Criterion
The Back Door Criterion (BDC) is a relatively quick-and-easy test to evaluate if a set of nodes is sufficient to answer the question of identifiability. In other words, it tells us what variables we need to measure to calculate a particular causal effect.
Before defining the BDC, we first must arm ourselves with two key concepts: a back-door path and blocking.
A back-door path between 2 nodes (say X and Y) is any path that starts with an arrow pointing into X and terminates at Y [3 (http://me.dm/r-jpDipto7eR?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. For example, these are all the back door paths in the graph below.
X  Z3 -> Y
X  Z3  Y
X  Y
X  Y

Example DAG to evaluate Back Door Criterion. Image by author.
Notice that we ignore the arrowheads when constructing back-door paths (except, of course, for the one pointing into X). The intuition behind back door paths is they carry spurious associations between 2 variables [2 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
].
The 2nd key concept here is that of blocking [3 (http://me.dm/r-jpDipto7eR?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. A path p is said to be blocked by a set of nodes {Z_i} if and only if,
p contains a chain A -> B -> C or a fork A  C, such that B is an element in {Z_i} - This is what we might intuitively think of as blocking
p contains a collider (i.e. an inverted fork) A -> B - No node in {Z_i} creates a spurious statistical association (Berkson's Paradox)

We can now combine these concepts to define the back door criterion [3 (http://me.dm/r-jpDipto7eR?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
].
Back Door Criterion - A set of nodes {Z_i} satisfy the BDC relative to (X, Y) if,
No node is a descendant of X (i.e. {Z_i} exclusively sit in back-door paths)
{Z_i} blocks every back door path between X and Y

Applying the BDC to the above graph, we can see that two sets of nodes satisfy this criterion [2 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
].
{Z1, Z3}
{Z1, Z2, Z3}

Notice the set {Z3} does not satisfy the BDC because it is a collider and thus does not satisfy our definition of blocking from before.
The sets {Z1, Z3} and {Z1, Z2, Z3} are called sufficient sets (also admissible sets). They tell us which variables to measure to calculate unbiased causal effects between X and Y. We can express the interventional distribution using the following equation whenever the BDC is satisfied.

Interventional distribution expressed in terms of observational distributions when Back Door Criterion is satisfied. Image by author.
Note on Propensity Score Methods
A key point connecting the back door criterion to the Propensity Score (PS) methods we saw in an earlier blog (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/propensity-score-5c29c480130c)
 is Propensity Score methods fail when the back door criterion is not satisfied [2 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. In other words, if the variables used to derive a propensity score do not make up a sufficient set, they may introduce bias into the causal effect estimate.
While one may (naively) think the more variables used in the PS model, the better, this can backfire [5 (http://me.dm/r--OJHaox92i?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. In some cases, like with variable Z3 in the above DAG, including particular variables may increase propensity score matching bias [2 (http://me.dm/r-h8ff1jfXhq?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
].
2) Front Door Criterion
Another quick-and-easy test we can use to evaluate identifiability is the Front Door criterion (FDC) [3 (http://me.dm/r-jpDipto7eR?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1669654102437-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b896219b_1ffb_43e8_8d38_e13c1ca0e609--------3ec6dd6333f3)
]. A set of nodes {Z_i} satisfy the FDC relative to (X, Y) if
{Z_i} intercepts all directed paths from X to Y
All back door paths from X to {Z_i} are blocked by the empty set
All back door paths from {Z_i} to Y are blocked by X

Let's look at another example. Consider the DAG below.

Example DAG to evaluate Front Door Criterion. Image by author.
We can first seek a set of variables that satisfies condition 1. To do that, we enumerate all the directed paths from X and Y. In this case, there are only 2.
X -> Z1 -> Y
X -> Z2 -> Y

From this, we can see only one set satisfies condition 1, {Z1, Z2}. But we aren't done yet. We need to check whether this set satisfied the FDC by checking it against conditions 2 and 3.
To check condition 2, we need to look at all the back door paths from X to every node in {Z1, Z2}.
X and Z1
X  Y 
X  Z3 -> Y 

X and Z2
X  Y 
X  Z3 -> Y 

We can see that all these paths are blocked because they include a collider Y.
Then finally, we check condition 3 by looking at all the back door paths between every variable in {Z1, Z2} and Y.
Z1 and Y
Z1  Y
Z1  Z3 -> Y
Z1  Z2 -> Y
Z1  Z2  Y

Z2 and Y
Z2  Y
Z2  Z3 -> Y
Z2  Z1 -> Y

And indeed, we see that all these paths are blocked by X. Thus, we conclude that in order to estimate the causal effect of X and Y, we need only measure variables X, Y, Z1, and Z2. We can do this using the equation below, which expresses the interventional distribution P(Y|do(x)) in terms of observational distributions, including X, Y, Z1, and Z2

Interventional distribution expressed in terms of observational distributions when Front Door Criterion is satisfied. Image by author.
Notice for each variable in {Z_i}, we sum over all possible values of variable X. Writing things out a little more explicitly for the above example we have.

Interventional distribution for the FDC example DAG given above. Image by author.
Key Points:
Identifiability is concerned with answering the question: can the causal effect be evaluated from the given data?
The 3 Rules of Do-Calculus gives us a complete set of operations to evaluate identifiability.
We can also evaluate identifiability via two quick-and-easy graphical tests: the Back Door Criterion and the Front Door Criterion.

···

subject: Smoothing Financial Time Series with Wavelets
body:
A real-world use case and example in Python

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1670614826846-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------f20852c9_0111_4d5f_81ec_bec626a5e14c--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
5 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/p/79645a44aa40?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1670614826846-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------f20852c9_0111_4d5f_81ec_bec626a5e14c--------3ec6dd6333f3)

Smoothing Noisy Time Series with Wavelets
A real-world use case and example in Python

Photo by Maxim Hopman on Unsplash
My goal with this walk-through is to showcase what data science projects look like in the "real world". While this is a simple use case, the data and problem are from reality (as opposed to a classroom).
Here I will walk through the problem, break down different solutions, and share my thoughts along the way. Python example code is provided below.
···
Background
A friend of mine is working on a project to automatically trade cryptocurrencies. He has some strategy (I don't know the details) that uses the time series plotted below to make buy/sell decisions. He reached out to me because his strategy was giving undesirable results due to the volatility of the time series.
Initial thoughts:
What is this data?
Why do you need to use this particular time series?
Is an alternative strategy using different data possible?

My friend's noisy time series data. Image by author.
Solutions
Existing Solution: Moving Average
My first thought would be to simply apply a moving average to the data. It turns out my friend had already tried this.
While at first glance this seems to do a fine job, this did not fully resolve the problem. Without knowing too much about the details of his technique I see 3 possible issues.
3 possible issues:
The signal still shows rapid changes in particular sections
There are time-shifting artifacts from the moving average
The optimal window size for the moving average is likely dynamic

Same time series from before (blue) and smoothed version using a moving average (orange). Image by author.
1st Attempt: Polynomial Fit (failed)
I interpreted this as an approximation problem. In other words, we have some function and we want to approximate it in such a way that we only keep the most relevant properties.
When I think "function", my first thought is polynomial. So the idea then became, to fit the data to a polynomial and keep only the "most relevant" terms.
This is a good example of when expectations and intuitions fail. I was so confident this quick and easy fix would work, the project seemed trivial. While this solution was indeed quick, it definitely did not work out as expected as you can see below.

Same time series from before (blue) and smoothed version using a polynomial fit (orange). Image by author.
2nd Attempt: Fourier Transform (failed)
Next, I thought, of course polynomials don't work they want to go to -∞ and +∞. The data here seem to oscillate around zero.
This made me think of sines and cosines. The idea was thus, to fit the data to a family of cosine and sine functions, then drop higher order terms, just like I did with the polynomials.
While sinusoidal fits exist, it often makes more sense to reframe the problem in terms of a Fourier Transform (FT). This is for practical reasons because we can use the computationally efficient and widely-used Fast Fourier Transform. So the idea then became, to decompose the signal using a Fourier Transform, then keep only coefficients above a certain threshold.
This worked to some extent but I'd say the moving average solution is both simpler and qualitatively better.
2 keys issues I see with this solution are:
The signal is still pretty noisy
The optimal coefficient threshold may be dynamic

Same time series from before (blue) and smoothed version using an FT-based method (orange). Image by author.
Final Solution: Wavelet Decomposition
Fourier-based approaches rely on sinusoids that extend from -∞ to +∞ (on the x-axis now). While this can be a feature of the technique, in this case, I'd say it's an issue.
My intuition for this is that the time series may have a variety of regimes, where the underlying generator of the signal is changing over time. What this would translate to is behavior that appears in one time range but not others.
Such localized oscillations bring up the concept of a wavelet, which is essentially a wave-like thing that is localized in time.
So, here we do an analogous approach to the previous solutions, but instead of decomposing the data to a family of polynomials or sinusoids, we use wavelets.
The result seems to be a nice balance of capturing the dynamics of the underlying signal but removing much of the volatility.

Same time series from before (blue) and smoothed version using the wavelet-based method (orange). Image by author.
Python Code
The Python code to generate the above plot is given below. The dataset is available at the GitHub repo (http://me.dm/r-tXFLe3IH9q?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1670614826846-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------f20852c9_0111_4d5f_81ec_bec626a5e14c--------3ec6dd6333f3)
, along with a Jupyter Notebook (http://me.dm/r-HTwM90WOZY?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1670614826846-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------f20852c9_0111_4d5f_81ec_bec626a5e14c--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 with code for the other 3 solutions.
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

import pywt

df = pd.read_csv('z_rate.csv')

x = df.index
y = df['z_avgRate']

# perform wavelet decomposition
coeffs = pywt.wavedec(y, 'sym5', mode='symmetric')

# zero out last 5 detail coefficents
for i in range(5):
    coeffs[i+5] = np.zeros(coeffs[i+5].shape)

# reconstruct wavelet
y_rec = pywt.waverec(coeffs, 'sym5', mode='symmetric')[1:]

# plot result
plt.figure(figsize=(18,6))
plt.plot(x, y)
plt.plot(x, y_rec)
plt.legend(['original', 'wavelet-based smoothing'])
plt.xlabel('time index')
plt.show()
···
Resources
More on Time Series Analysis: Fourier Transform (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/time-series-signals-the-fourier-transform-f68e8a97c1c2)
 | FFT (http://me.dm/r-qHFtoqOM2H?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1670614826846-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------f20852c9_0111_4d5f_81ec_bec626a5e14c--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 | Wavelet Transform (http://me.dm/r-Dh3qFVq0Wm?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1670614826846-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------f20852c9_0111_4d5f_81ec_bec626a5e14c--------3ec6dd6333f3)

subject: A Billionaire Told Me to Read This Book
body:
10 rules that changed the way I think about wealth

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1671503987017-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------72f76fd6_0d0d_4446_8ad0_838d2a82fe78--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
3 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/p/d7705ad441c5?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1671503987017-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------72f76fd6_0d0d_4446_8ad0_838d2a82fe78--------3ec6dd6333f3)

A Billionaire Told Me to Read This Book
10 rules that changed the way I think about wealth

Photo by Taylor on Unsplash
Out of all the books in his library, this was the "only one" worth reading.
I was never much of a reader in high school or college. This stemmed from the idea that not trying in school and still getting good grades somehow made me cool - I guess being dumb and poor was cool.
So what would drive a cool kid like me to read a book?
Well, I found myself talking to a billionaire.
I had never met a billionaire before, so I didn't know what to expect. But to the surprise of my 20-year-old self, he was just a person.. a person who had accumulated more wealth than everyone I had ever met combined 😳.
···
The Question
This was a unique opportunity. It is not often one meets a billionaire. I had to learn something from this person. So I asked a simple question.
Me: "… I noticed your library. What books do you recommend?"
The question was a bit abrupt in hindsight, but after a brief pause, he responded.
Billionaire: "There is only one book in there worth reading."
Okay, now I'm intrigued.
Billionaire: "It's called, The Richest Man In Babylon"
The Richest Man in Babylon
I bought the book on Amazon almost immediately.
The key premise of the book is this: the rules of wealth have not changed since ancient times.
The book lays out this ancient wisdom through a series of tales taking place in the ancient city of Babylon.

The "Richest Man In Babylon" book. Image by author.
10 Rules for Building Wealth
Some of these rules may be obvious and some maybe not. However, just knowing the rules is half the game, the other half is actually doing something about it.
Building wealth is a skill. You can get good at it if you know the rules and practice them.
Pay yourself first. Saving 10% of your income is a good start.
Live on less than you earn. It sounds obvious, yet a lot of people can't seem to do it.
Make your money work for you. This means investments. Anything that you put money in and get more money out. Owning your home is a simple one.
People are hesitant to give out money, but they are (usually) happy to give out wisdom. The latter is so much more valuable. When you have the chance to learn from someone ahead of you, use it!
What translates a desire for gold into reality is knowledge. The more you know the more you can earn.
Level up your capacity to earn. Rules 5 - 7 have a lot of overlap, but it's super important! Information and knowledge are what create income.
There is more than enough gold to go around, you just need to learn the rules of the game and practice them (Abundance mindset).
Luck comes to those who put themselves out there. "Good luck and be enticed by accepting the opportunity."
When you finally get money, protect it from loss. Beware of investments outside your expertise. If it is outside your expertise, be sure to work with an expert you can trust. And most importantly, don't lose all your money.

···

subject: Causal Effects via Regression
body:
3 Popular Techniques With Python Example Code

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1673321637920-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------1a3b749e_088b_4e87_8b1f_005e4fb7d5f5--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 in Towards Data Science (https://medium.com/towards-data-science?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1673321637920-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------1a3b749e_088b_4e87_8b1f_005e4fb7d5f5--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
8 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/28cb58a2fffc?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1673321637920-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------1a3b749e_088b_4e87_8b1f_005e4fb7d5f5--------3ec6dd6333f3)

Causal Effects via Regression
3 Popular Techniques With Python Example Code
This is the 5th article in a series on causal effects (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/causal-effects-f30f962ffff3)
. In previous articles, we discussed different ways to compute treatment effects from data. Here I introduce an alternative approach to estimating causal effects via 3 popular regression-based techniques. I finish the article with example Python code of how one can use these techniques in practice.
Key Points:
Regression is a way to learn relationships between variables using data
3 popular regression-based approaches for estimating causal effects are: linear regression, double machine learning, and meta-learners

Toy example of causal effect via linear regression. Image by author.
···
What is regression?

Understanding Causal Effects
Review and Summary of a 5-part Series
In this article, I review and summarize key points from a 5-part series on causal effects (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/causal-effects-f30f962ffff3)
. While only a high-level contour is given here, further details and references can be found in the subsequent articles linked below. Additionally, each post has an associated video walkthrough on YouTube.

If I take one pill I feel good, but what if I take two? Image by author.
···

1) Introduction
What is a causal effect? Causal effects quantify the impact of a treatment by comparing outcomes of different treatment levels. This is synonymous with treatment effects, which are used interchangeably throughout this series. Put another way, causal effects go beyond questions…

Decision Trees: Introduction & Intuition
Making data-informed decisions with Python
This is the first article in a series on Decision Trees. In this post, I introduce decision trees and describe how to grow them using data. The post concludes with example Python code showing how to create and use a decision tree to help make medical prognoses.
Key Points:
Decision Trees are a widely-used and intuitive machine learning technique used to solve prediction problems.
We can grow decision trees from data.
Hyperparameter tuning can be used to help avoid the overfitting problem.

Photo by niko photos on Unsplash peppered with thinking emojis.

Decision trees are a widely-used and intuitive machine learning technique. Typically, they are used to solve prediction problems. …

body:
Breaking down bagging, boosting, Random Forest, and AdaBoost

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1677512440343-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------dcaa814f_463f_4b79_8891_0a25dc9c2950--------3ec6dd6333f3)

10 Decision Trees are Better Than 1
Breaking down bagging, boosting, Random Forest, and AdaBoost
This is the 2nd article in a series on decision trees. In the last post (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/decision-trees-introduction-intuition-dac9592f4b7f)
, we introduced decision trees and discussed how to grow them using data. While they are an intuitive machine learning approach, decision trees are prone to overfitting. Here we discuss a solution to this overfitting problem via decision tree ensembles.
Key points:
Decision tree ensembles combine several decision trees into a single estimator
Tree ensembles are less prone to overfitting than a single decision tree

Drake doesn't like single decision trees. He prefers ensembles. Image by author.

subject: 2 “Next-Level” Uses of Decision Trees
body:
How to reduce predictor count and segment variables

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1678551576622-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------cdad3b5a_2e8a_4eec_90a4_ccd70de46a9a--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
9 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/p/80f60b3c61d9?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1678551576622-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------cdad3b5a_2e8a_4eec_90a4_ccd70de46a9a--------3ec6dd6333f3)

2 "Next-Level" Uses of Decision Trees
How to reduce predictor count and segment variables
This is the 3rd article in a series on decision trees. Thus far, we've discussed how to build predictive models using decision trees (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/decision-trees-introduction-intuition-dac9592f4b7f)
 and tree ensembles (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/10-decision-trees-are-better-than-1-719406680564)
. While this is the core use of these techniques, we can use them for more than just making predictions. In this post, I walk through 2 additional uses of decision trees that can take your analytics work to the next level.

Image from KnowYourMeme. Mutation by author.
···
Next-level?
In the 1st article of this series, I defined a model as something that allows us to make predictions. For example, predicting tomorrow's weather forecast or the probability of developing heart disease.
We saw one way to get a model was by using decision trees. While predictions are a common application of decision trees, that is not their only use.
This brings up "next-level" data science methods. By this, I mean methods that go beyond the obvious task of building a predictive model toward using the model (or models) to do something more interesting (which is what data science in the real world is all about).
While data science may seem as easy and simple as training a model with a few lines of code using sklearn, the real (and fun) work is figuring out how to use a model to solve a problem and provide value.
Here I share two such uses of decision trees. Although both examples use medical data, these techniques can be applied to virtually any context (e.g. credit risk, sales, marketing, etc.) All Python code (as always) is freely available at the GitHub repo (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-lBe4iNR4kA?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1678551576622-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------cdad3b5a_2e8a_4eec_90a4_ccd70de46a9a--------3ec6dd6333f3)
.
Use 1: Reduce Predictor Count
In the last blog (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/10-decision-trees-are-better-than-1-719406680564)
 of this series, we used decision tree ensembles to do breast cancer prediction. While this was an instructive example, it may be challenging to realize the value of these models.
One issue is that the tree ensemble methods we used are black boxes. We know what goes in and out comes out, but aren't too sure about what happens in between.
Sure, we could plot every decision tree in the ensemble, look at its splits, and compare relative model weights, but with 30 predictor variables and 100 constituent models, it might be difficult to pull out an intuitive understanding.
For these cases, we can call upon Occam's Razor. This principle implies that simpler models are better. In the context of a tree ensemble, we can translate this to fewer predictor variables are better.
There are two main upsides to this. One, interpreting a model with 3 variables is easier than one with 30. And two, fewer predictor variables mean less possibility of failure (this comes from the engineering wisdom that the more moving parts a system has, the greater the opportunity for failure).
So, the question becomes: how do we pick which variables to keep?
One way is via our model's feature importance ranking. The basic idea is we use the importance ranking to add variables to a model (one at a time) and compare model performances.
While this does not guarantee an optimal choice of predictor variables, it does provide us with a quick and easy heuristic for developing simpler models. Let's see what this might look like for the breast cancer prediction problem from the previous blog (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/10-decision-trees-are-better-than-1-719406680564)
.
We start with importing libraries.
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

from sklearn.datasets import load_breast_cancer # toy dataset (sorry)

from imblearn.over_sampling import SMOTE

from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression
from sklearn.metrics import roc_auc_score
Next, we import our data and define our predictor and target variables.
# define predictor and target variable names
X_var_names = df.columns[:df.shape[1]-1]
y_var_name = df.columns[df.shape[1]-1]

# create predictor and target arrays
X = df[X_var_names]
y = df[y_var_name]

# transform y such that 1=>malignant and 0=>benign
y = -1*y + 1
The last line of the above code block is doing a simple transformation of the target variable to convert every 0 → 1 and 1 → 0. This will help us interpret predictors as driving breast cancer risk as opposed to "safety."
Since we have an imbalanced dataset, i.e. we have more benign than malignant tumor cases, we can make our data balanced using SMOTE.
# oversample minority class using smote
X_resampled, y_resampled = SMOTE(random_state=0).fit_resample(X, y)

# create train and test datasets using balanced
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X_resampled, y_resampled, test_size=0.2, random_state=0)
Now to the fun part. We start by training a Random Forest model.
clf = RandomForestClassifier(random_state=0)
clf = clf.fit(X_train, y_train)
We can evaluate its performance via the area under the curve (AUC) of the ROC plot. I won't get into the details of AUC here. I will just say an AUC close to 1 means a good model, and 0 means a bad model.
rf_auc_val = roc_auc_score(y_test, clf.predict_proba(X_test)[:,1])
print(rf_auc_val)

# >>> 0.995266272189349
Now with our model, we can spit out a feature importance ranking.
feature_importances = pd.Series(clf.feature_importances_, index=X_var_names)
feature_importances_sorted = feature_importances.sort_values(ascending=False)
print(feature_importances_sorted)
The printout looks like this.

Feature importance printed in descending order. Image by author.
With the predictor importance, we can go down the list one feature at a time and add it to a Logistic Regression model. The result of this will be 30 Logistic Regression models with increasing predictor counts, i.e. the 1st model with only use worst perimeter, the 2nd will use worst perimeter and mean concave points, and the 3rd worst perimeter, mean concave points, and worst radius.
The code to do this looks like this.
# intialize lists
base_clf_list = []
train_auc_list = []
test_auc_list = []

i=0
for i in range(len(feature_importances_sorted)):

    feature_names = list(feature_importances_sorted.index[:i+1])
    base_clf = LogisticRegression(random_state=0, solver='newton-cg').fit(X_train[feature_names], y_train)

    base_clf_list.append(base_clf)
    train_auc_list.append(roc_auc_score(y_train, base_clf.predict_proba(X_train[feature_names])[:,1]))
    test_auc_list.append(roc_auc_score(y_test, base_clf.predict_proba(X_test[feature_names])[:,1]))
Then we can plot how performance evolves with the addition of each variable for both the training and testing datasets.

Model performance plotted against the number of variables. Image by author.
We can see from the plot above that the Logistic Regression model with 5 variables outperforms the Random Forest model with 30 variables!
Beyond the performance gain, Logistic Regression is a linear mode. Therefore, we can interpret predictor impacts on the target by simply looking at each predictor variable's coefficient.
Visualizing the coefficient in a bar chart.

Coefficients for Logistic Regression model with 5 input variables. Image by author.
The way to interpret these coefficients is a unit increase in the associated predictor variable translates to an increase in breast cancer risk equal to the coefficient value. For example, an increase of worst perimeter by 1 unit means breast cancer risk will increase by about 0.31. Here, "breast cancer risk" means the log odds of the tumor being malignant.
Technical note: we re-sampled our training and testing data which leads to bias in the model's intercept. Thus, we can't (yet) translate the log odds of malignant into an (unbiased) probability of malignant. However, there is a simple fix for this, which is to adjust the intercept (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-XrYtjzRI6b?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1678551576622-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------cdad3b5a_2e8a_4eec_90a4_ccd70de46a9a--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 for the oversampling procedure.
Use 2: Predictor Segmentation
The example from the 1st blog (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/decision-trees-introduction-intuition-dac9592f4b7f)
 of this series used a single decision tree to do sepsis survival prediction. There we saw that age drove the bulk of the decision tree splits, indicating it was a key risk factor for sepsis survival.
In cases like this, where one predictor variable has an outsized impact on the target variable, it can make sense to segment data records using the high-impact predictor.
For example, if age is the main driver of sepsis survival we can segment patients into different age buckets, then develop age-bucket-specific survival models. Two benefits of this are: 1) this is it gives lower impact predictors a chance to reveal their predictive power, and 2) different age groups may have systematic differences that require separate modeling.
While we could develop these age buckets manually (or arbitrarily), another option is to let the data tell us the optimal age groups. In other words, we can learn age bucket definitions from our data.
It turns out we can use a decision tree to do this in a straightforward way. We simply train a decision tree model only using the high-impact predictor (e.g. age) to estimate the target (e.g. survival flag).
Let's use the sepsis survival problem as an example. We again start by importing some Python libraries.
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

from sklearn import tree
Next, we import our data and group it by age. Additionally, we can use the sepsis survival flag to compute the percent_alive and percent_not_alive for each age value.
# keep only age and sepsis survival flag
df = df.iloc[:,[0,3]]

# group data by age and compute percent alive for each age value
df_byAge = (df.groupby(by=df.columns[0]).sum()/df.groupby(by=df.columns[0]).count())
df_byAge.columns = ['percent_alive']
df_byAge['percent_not_alive'] = 1 - df_byAge['percent_alive']
The resulting dataframe looks like this.

Pandas dataframe after the preparation step. Image by author.
Next, we can define separate data frames for our predictor and target variables. Here we will use age_years to predict percent_not_alive.
# define predictor and target variable names
X_var_name = df_byAge.columns[0]
y_var_name = df_byAge.columns[2]

# create predictor and target arrays
X = df_byAge[X_var_name]
y = df_byAge[y_var_name]
To get a sense of the relationship between age and sepsis risk, we can plot the two variables against each other.

Sepsis death rate by age. Image by author.
As expected, the risk of sepsis increases with age. It is interesting to note the uptick in risk around mid-life.
Next, we use a decision tree to segment this data. Again, the goal is to split the data into different age groups based on sepsis risk, which can be framed as a modeling problem.
First, we train a univariate decision tree to predict percent_not_alive.
num_bins = 4

# train model
clf = tree.DecisionTreeRegressor(random_state=42, max_leaf_nodes=num_bins)
clf = clf.fit(X.to_numpy().reshape(-1, 1), y)
Notice we constrained the growth of the decision tree using the max_leaf_nodes argument. What this does is determine the number of age buckets we derive i.e. 4 bins implies 4 age buckets.
Next, we can traverse the decision tree and extract each age split value.
# variables creation
num_nodes = clf.tree_.node_count
left_child = clf.tree_.children_left
right_child = clf.tree_.children_right
threshold = clf.tree_.threshold

# list to store the bin edges
bin_edge_list = [X[0],X[len(X)-1]]

# loop through all the nodes
for i in range(num_nodes):
    # If the left and right child of a node is not the same(-1) we have an internal node
    # which we will append to bin_node list
    if left_child[i]!=right_child[i]:
        bin_edge_list.append(np.round(threshold[i],1))

# sort the nodes in increasing order
bin_edge_list.sort()

# create dictionary to store epoch bin edges
bin_dict = {}

# put in each dictionary index 2 consecutive bin edges
for i in range(num_bins):
    bin_dict[str(i+1)] = [bin_edge_list[i], bin_edge_list[i+1]]
While this code snippet is a little technical, we can simply plot the extracted bin edges from our plot from before.

Sepsis death rate by age with 4 decision tree-based age buckets. Image by author.
We can see the age buckets do a qualitatively good job of splitting age groups based on risk. These buckets can be used to inform sepsis risk tiers, treatment strategies for different age groups, or age-bucket-specific risk modeling.
···
Resources

subject: On April 12, we’re saying goodbye to custom themes on Medium profiles
body:
Hi there,
A few years ago, we introduced new tools to help you customize your Medium profile with background colors, accent colors, and fonts.
In the time since launch, we haven’t seen the widespread adoption we’d anticipated for. We also want Medium to be accessible to everyone—and as much as we appreciate the flexibility of custom profile themes, we know they can make reading more difficult for people with color blindness or other visual sensitivities. (If you’ve ever abruptly switched from dark to light-background pages while browsing Medium, you know how tiring on the eyes it can be.)
For these reasons, we’re ending support for custom profile background colors, accent colors, and fonts on April 12. If you’ve set a full-page custom background color on your profile and story pages, it will revert to white; profile accent colors will revert to green. Profile fonts will revert to sans serif for headings and serif for body text.
Profile header colors and imagery will not be affected by this change—your profile page header is still fully customizable, and you’ll still be able to edit it at medium.com/me/design. Publication colors and fonts will not be affected by this change, either.
We know many of you have put a lot of time and care into designing your profiles, which is why we wanted to give you advance notice. Please feel free to email us at writersupport@medium.com with any questions about this change.
—Harris Sockel, Buster Benson, and the team @ Medium

subject: We Need More (Data) Entrepreneurs
body:
Our best defense against AI-induced inequality

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1680973442677-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------06ccee12_687f_4b88_87c7_acf8a59a3d37--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 in The Data Entrepreneurs (https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1680973442677-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------06ccee12_687f_4b88_87c7_acf8a59a3d37--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
4 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs/27f0312c67f3?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1680973442677-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------06ccee12_687f_4b88_87c7_acf8a59a3d37--------3ec6dd6333f3)

We Need More (Data) Entrepreneurs
Our best defense against AI-induced inequality

Photo by NASA on Unsplash
Rice on a Chessboard
Innovation builds on top of itself. Electricity enabled computers, computers enabled the internet, the internet enabled social media, and social media enabled me to post selfies from my trip to Cancun 😎.
A key consequence of this (recursive) property is that innovation scales exponentially, which is like 1 -> 2 -> 4 -> 8 -> 16.
This might seem tame initially, but after just a couple dozen iterations, the numbers get much bigger i.e. 16,777,216 -> 33,554,432 -> 67,108,864.

Exponential growth illustrated by doubling the number of rice grains placed on subsequent chessboard squares. Image by author.
Reality is (probably) a bit messier than a pure exponential, but there are periods when innovation accelerates rapidly. We call these time periods "Revolutions."
The AI Revolution
The Industrial Revolution gave us the steam engine. The Digital Revolution gave us computers. And now, we are living in another revolution: The AI Revolution.
Tools like ChatGPT, Stable Diffusion 2, and many others have given us a flavor of what will come over the next decades. This era will create more technology, wealth, and innovation than any other in human history.
While this will bring tremendous good to the world, it also generates significant risks.
My Toaster Took My Job
There are many concerns surrounding AI: mass unemployment due to automation, misinformation & cyber attacks fueled by generative AI, or the potential of an Age of Ultron situation (or Terminator, for the more experienced).

(Evil) toaster stole my retail job. Image by author.
While these pose various degrees of risk, there is one concern that doesn't receive as much attention.
Big Opportunities for a Small Population
A concern not enough people talk about is we have too much opportunity on the table.
I know what you're thinking, "Uh.. Shaw, that doesn't sound like a problem". But think of it like this: what happens when a large number of opportunities go to a small number of people?
Big opportunity distributed among a few players creates inequality. This means a handful of organizations with an outsized share of the money, resources, and human capital.
Furthermore, with an exponentially growing number of possible AI innovations and applications, there is no way a single organization (or even several organizations) can fully exploit this potential.
We Need More Entrepreneurs
The solution here is simple. We need more entrepreneurs.
We need more people who understand this technology to keep up with the exponentially growing space of opportunities. If not, these opportunities will default to the small number of people driving the innovation (i.e. large tech companies).
Data Entrepreneurs
The trouble is most people don't understand AI from a technical lens, and of those who do, many are not entrepreneurs. However, those who check both boxes are exactly who we need in this AI revolution.

The Data Entrepreneur checklist. Image by author.
Entrepreneurs without technical know-how will struggle with these new technologies. On the other hand, data scientists and AI researchers without entrepreneurial tendencies will gravitate toward large organizations (further driving AI inequality).
Why I'm Optimistic
What makes this revolution different than those of the past is access. With the global availability of information and the cost of computation approaching zero, the barrier to entry has never been so low.
Virtually anyone with a computer and an internet connection can be a player (not just an observer) in the AI revolution.
Where do I start?
There are many roads to data entrepreneurship. While this means there is no single set of directions for people to follow, here are some possible next steps.
Carve out an hour a day to learn more about AI.
Connect with other data entrepreneurs and learn from each other (we have a Discord (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-xbK4KZPVAy?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1680973442677-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------06ccee12_687f_4b88_87c7_acf8a59a3d37--------3ec6dd6333f3)
!)
Identify a problem that would bring you great misery if never solved, then pursue it.
Create content based on your data expertise/passions and share it online (this is a great way to learn and connect with others)
Pick-up data contract work on platforms like Upwork or Fiverr (this is a great way to explore the space of possible AI use cases while developing your technical skills)
Set aside 2–4 hours a week to pursue interesting projects.

···
Resources
Connect: My website (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-veicciWvZK?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1680973442677-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------06ccee12_687f_4b88_87c7_acf8a59a3d37--------3ec6dd6333f3)

subject: Why a Community Will 10X Your Chances of Success
body:
And My Desperate Search For Data Entrepreneurs

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1681734186226-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------ccb3dc89_c501_4876_ad02_3e6989396a74--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 in The Data Entrepreneurs (https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1681734186226-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------ccb3dc89_c501_4876_ad02_3e6989396a74--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
4 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs/e6fc6262eb16?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1681734186226-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-a47c2ab4d9da------------------------ccb3dc89_c501_4876_ad02_3e6989396a74--------3ec6dd6333f3)

Why a Community Will 10X Your Chances of Success
And My Desperate Search For Data Entrepreneurs

Photo by Chang Duong on Unsplash
A Lesson From Mr. Beast
In an interview [1], ultra-mega-YouTuber Mr. Beast attributed his early YouTube success to 2 things. 1) being completely obsessed and 2) being surrounded by people who are also obsessed.
Imagine either of these without the other. Obsession is powerful, but even a mediocre team can out-produce a highly motivated individual. On the other hand, a community is powerful, but the details of who you surround yourself with matter (being a member of "Pizza & Pints" won't help you with your weight loss goals.)
The Power of Community
This is a testament to the power of a community of like-minded individuals. A (great) team is more than the sum of its parts, which means something special happens when the right people work together. There's a magic that makes their output together far greater than if apart.
But why is that? What's so special about a community of like-minded individuals?
Here are some thoughts:
The group can cover more ground than the individual. So everyone learns lessons faster.
The group can do more repetitions than the individual. So everyone develops skills faster.
The group can build more than the individual. So everyone makes a bigger impact.

Where the Data Entrepreneurs at?
I have always been inspired by the idea of a community like this. This is what motivated me to seek out such a community in the realm of data entrepreneurship i.e. technical data people who also have an entrepreneurial itch.
However, as I searched Google and Reddit, the results were bleak. There were communities of data folks (mainly people working in technical roles) and communities of entrepreneurs, but not many communities of both.

"Sorry, no data entrepreneur communities." Image by author.
This is Harder Than I Thought
While it may be easy to imagine your ideal community, actually finding it is much harder. In my case, we're talking about: data science and entrepreneurship. Either one is can be enough for anyone.
The niche felt too niche.
But instead of submitting to this roadblock, I kept going. And turned the obstacle into an opportunity.
How to find your ideal community
With about 5 billion people on the internet, there is practically nothing that is "too niche." If you are genuinely passionate about something, it is almost certain that others are too. You just have to find them.
"Okay.. but how the heck do I find these needles in the world's biggest haystack!?"
It's simple, you don't. They find you.
"If you build it, they will come"
For all the criticisms and concerns surrounding social media, it is really good at one thing: showing people content they want to see.
Therefore, one strategy for finding your ideal community is to make content specifically for them.
Every piece of content you create is an opportunity to for a new connection. And every connection you make with someone like-minded is one step closer to your ideal community.
It may take a lot of steps, but if you do it long enough, you will get there.
And so, with this roadmap, The Data Entrepreneurs was born.
The Data Entrepreneurs (TDE)

What is TDE?
The Data Entrepreneurs (TDE) is a community for entrepreneurs working in the data space. Data entrepreneurs bring together the technical skillset of a data professional and the mindset of an entrepreneur in the pursuit of data-centered ventures.
What is the goal of TDE?
The main goal of TDE is to foster the development of data-focused people, projects, and businesses.
Who is TDE for?
Data professional trying to start a business
Recent grads seeking professional development and mentorship
Seasoned entrepreneurs who want to connect with AI and data experts
Professionals and researchers who want to stay informed on the latest AI and data trends
Data freelancers looking for a supportive community
Content creators seeking feedback and inspiration
Mentors who want to help guide the next generation of entrepreneurs

What does someone get out of TDE?
Support and guidance from community members
Networking opportunities
Collaboration on projects
Access to contractors and contracts
Events focused on AI, data tech, and entrepreneurship
Idea incubation
Community discussions
Learning from and teaching others in the field
Peer review (code, articles, projects, etc.)
Mentorship opportunities

How to join?
Follow us on Medium: https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs
Join the Discord 👇

subject: How to Make a (Free) Data Science Portfolio Website With GitHub Pages
body:
5 easy steps toward your next data science role

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1682774546183-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------57666a8c_9091_41ad_b80a_5af6367e54d6--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
6 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/p/aa1e4965e155?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1682774546183-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------57666a8c_9091_41ad_b80a_5af6367e54d6--------3ec6dd6333f3)

How to Make a (Free) Data Science Portfolio Website With GitHub Pages
5 easy steps toward your next data science role

By the end of this article, you will be able to create your own data science portfolio from scratch using GitHub Pages.
Technical Skills Aren't Enough
Getting a job as a data scientist is not all about your programming and ML chops. A big part of getting hired is selling yourself.
Unfortunately, this tends to be a big weakness for data scientists because we don't typically focus on this skill set in our formal training or day-to-day work.
I was definitely in this boat when first looking for data science roles. However, one simple thing that helped me get my current job was making a portfolio website.
Aesthetics Go a Long Way
A (pretty) website helps you stand out and gives you credibility as a professional. It gives employers a landing page to learn more about you and your experience.
While this all sounds great, if you're a data scientist like me, then web development is probably not your strong suit (as can be seen in the screenshot below).

What happens when a data scientist makes a website. Image by author.
GitHub Pages
Lucky for us all, our good friend GitHub has a solution for this. GitHub Pages is a built-in function that lets you host a website from a GitHub repository for free! Furthermore, GitHub Pages is equipped with a package called Jekyll which automatically translates your repo's README.md file into a pretty website.
Recent UI change
I used GitHub Pages many times in grad school (2019–2022) to spin up project websites and my own portfolio. However, there was a recent change to the Pages user interface, which made the process a little different (and less convenient) than what is described on the GitHub Pages website (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-n0wVrXtpUQ?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1682774546183-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------57666a8c_9091_41ad_b80a_5af6367e54d6--------3ec6dd6333f3)
.
More details on UI change in YouTube Video 🎥 (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-vKdYv0i9It?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1682774546183-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------57666a8c_9091_41ad_b80a_5af6367e54d6--------3ec6dd6333f3)

While their outdated instructions sent me down a rabbit hole for a few hours, I finally nailed down a quick and easy (no-code) process for generating a portfolio website.
Here I break it into 5 easy steps, so you don't have to struggle like I did 😅.
Step 1) Create GitHub Repo
The first step is to create a new GitHub repository. An easy way to do this is: go to your GitHub profile > click on Repositories > click the green New button.
After doing this, you should get a screen like the one below.

Example GitHub repo configurations for a portfolio website. Image by author.
The first thing we need here is to set the repository name. This is important because it will dictate the default URL for your website. There are two options here.
The first option is to use username.github.io. For example, my user name is ShawhinT, so here I would type: shawhint.github.io. With this option, the repo name is identical to the website URL.
The second option is to use any name you like. For example, I can name the repo portfolio. Then my website URL will be: shawhint.github.io/portfolio.
Next, check the Add a README file box. Then click Create repository.
Step 2) Create _config.yml File
The second step is to select a theme for your website portfolio. Before the Pages interface change, this consisted of picking a theme using a built-in GUI.
However, this is no longer the case, and we now need to pick a theme via something called a _config.yml file. This file tells Jekyll how to take the text from our README file and generate a pretty website.
To make a _config.yml file, create a new file in your repo, as shown in the screenshot below.

How to create new file in GitHub repo. Image by author.
Now name your new file, _config.yml, and add the following contents to the file.
# add the following to _config.yml file
title: YOUR NAME
theme: jeykll-theme-minimal
Here I pick the "minimal" theme, which I like best for a portfolio. But there are other supported theme options. A full list of them can be found here: https://pages.github.com/themes/

Example config.yml file. Image by author.
Once that's done, commit the changes.
Step 3) Fill out README.md file
The third step is to fill out your README. This will become the content of your portfolio website. For now, we can put in basic information but will return back to this later.
The screenshot below shows a basic example of some initial content.

Example README.md file content. Image by author.
Once you have some basic info down, commit the changes.
Step 4) Build and Deploy Website
With the _config.yml and README.md files in place, you can deploy your website. To do this, go to your repo's settings.

Location of setting tab for GitHub repo. Image by author.
On the left-hand settings panel, click on the Pages option. Then, select the main branch as your deployment source and hit Save.

How to deploy website from main branch. Image by author.
Now, we can check the deployment status by navigating to the repo's action tab. Once you see the green check next to pages build and deployment, click Deployments on the left panel.

How to check deployment status. Image by author.
You'll reach a screen that looks like the screenshot below. From there, simply click View deployment to go to your website.

How to view website deployment. Image by author.
Below is an example of what you should be seeing. It is bare-bones for now, but I find it helpful to run through the whole process before going back and filling out the website content.

Bare-bones version of portfolio website. Image by author.
Step 5) Customize & Fine-tune
Now that we've seen the whole process, you can go back to your README.md file and customize your portfolio. If you want some inspiration, take a look at a finished example portfolio available at the GitHub repo below👇
Final product: https://shawhint.github.io/example-portfolio/
Feel free to steal the code and fill in the portfolio with your own experience. My initial strategy was to copy-paste content from my LinkedIn profile and resume.
However, in the next blog of this series, I will discuss resume/portfolio best practices that I've found helpful for landing data science roles.
In the meantime, if you have questions on this or a career in data science, feel free to reach out 😁.

subject: 5 Ways to Become a Data Scientist Without Work Experience
body:
Resolving the "I need experience to get a job, but need a job to get experience" loop

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1683807269996-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------c58b18ae_18c5_4fa3_95ce_ccd3a432a975--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
4 min read
  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/p/b36c401a88c0?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1683807269996-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------c58b18ae_18c5_4fa3_95ce_ccd3a432a975--------3ec6dd6333f3)

5 Ways to Become a Data Scientist Without Work Experience
Resolving the "I need experience to get a job, but need a job to get experience" loop

Photo by Campaign Creators on Unsplash
With its 6-figure salaries and rapid growth, data science is a highly sought-after industry [1]. However, for most, landing that first DS job and breaking into the field is a major challenge.
It's often the story of "you need experience to get a job, but you need a job to get experience."
While experience and jobs go hand in hand, I don't think this story is necessarily the case.
Meaning there are things other than past work experience that can make someone a desirable candidate for a data science role, and there are ways to get experience other than a…

subject: 5 Data Science Portfolio Mistakes
body:
How to make a portfolio that will get you hired

Shawhin Talebi (https://medium.com/@shawhin?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1684505410292-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------b7fc8226_3115_45e7_9573_38a7fca11127--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 in Towards Data Science (https://medium.com/towards-data-science?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1684505410292-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------b7fc8226_3115_45e7_9573_38a7fca11127--------3ec6dd6333f3)
  ∙  
5 min read  ∙  
View on Medium (https://medium.com/towards-data-science/52f6e0ebbe4a?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1684505410292-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-7f60cf5620c9------------------------b7fc8226_3115_45e7_9573_38a7fca11127--------3ec6dd6333f3)

5 Data Science Portfolio Mistakes
How to make a portfolio that will get you hired

Photo by Kenny Eliason on Unsplash
When trying to get hired as a data scientist, it's not just about what you know but also what you show. In other words, effectively conveying your expertise and past work is a critical part of the process.
One of the best ways to do this is via a portfolio website. A portfolio gives you credibility and makes your work readily available to clients and hiring managers.
However, not all portfolios are equal. There are key mistakes that separate bad portfolios from good ones. In this article, I break down 5 mistakes that will guarantee your portfolio never gets you hired.
Mistake 1: Don't make a portfolio website
The worst portfolio is no portfolio.

404 message for portfolio. Image by author.
Since most people don't have a portfolio, just having something will yield most of the benefits and give you an edge over other candidates.
However, if you've never made a website, you might be hesitant. You might worry that it'll cost money or you'll need to spend hours learning how to code in HTML and CSS.
I was in this boat too. Funny enough, it took me 8 months to make my first portfolio, not because of some tremendous cost or time commitment but because I held myself back. In fact, my first portfolio (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-iwB8aZMH8f?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1684505410292-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b7fc8226_3115_45e7_9573_38a7fca11127--------3ec6dd6333f3)
 didn't cost me anything and took me about a weekend to create.
With all the free tools out there, it's never been easier to make a website. For example, in a past article (https://medium.com/the-data-entrepreneurs/how-to-make-a-free-data-science-portfolio-website-with-github-pages-aa1e4965e155)
, I describe a free and easy way to create a portfolio (without code) using GitHub Pages.
Mistake 2: Include irrelevant projects
When you try to be everything to everyone, you're not right for anyone.
If you avoided mistake 1, the next step is picking the right projects to showcase. But what makes a project "right"?
An essential part of curating your portfolio is knowing your audience. Who is this for? What are they looking for? How can I directly speak to their needs?
For example, if looking for entry-level data science roles, pick projects that convey technical data skills (e.g. Python and SQL), and don't pick projects more suitable for software engineering or web development (e.g., javascript, HTML, etc). While the latter may be helpful in a data science role, they are not critical and are ultimately a distraction to your audience.
Additionally, choosing a niche can be beneficial here. Niching helps make you a big fish in a small pond and helps avoid the "I specialize in everything" pitch.
Even if this is true, this can make it difficult for your audience to see how you fit into their world. If the audience can't quickly connect what's on your portfolio to their problems, they will move on to the next candidate.
Mistake 3: Cram in as many Kaggle projects as possible
1 real-world project > 10 toy projects.
A mistake made by many when choosing projects is taking quantity over quality. This often manifests itself as portfolios full of projects using toy datasets from websites like Kaggle.
While these projects can be great educational tools, they lack essential elements of real-world data science projects, e.g. understanding the business problem, working within existing processes, and synthesizing data from multiple sources.
When trying to assess the quality of a project, focus on impact. Using impact as a filter for picking projects not only makes your work more impressive but also conveys that your work is relevant to someone in the world. Examples of impact could be: you won a hackathon, the work was published, it generated $X in savings, X number of people downloaded the project, you presented it in front of X people, etc.
For those just getting started and lacking good projects to choose from, the most obvious path is doing an independent project. While this is easier said than done, here are a few quick tips to help guide your effort.
Tailor projects to your interests or job description or (ideally) both
Acquire (real-world) data from an existing business or organization
Build a web scraper or explore public APIs to aggregate data
Contribute to open-source projects
Find a mentor

Mistake 4: Don't include any visuals
Show don't tell.
If the worst portfolio is no portfolio. The 2nd worst is a portfolio with no pictures.
The key advantage of a website is you can embed images, gifs, and videos, to not only describe your work but to show it. Rather than trying to make this point through words, consider the gif below.
On the left, I have a text description of the project, while on the right, I simply show a demo. Which do you find more compelling?

Showing vs. telling. (Left) Text description of the project. (Right) Video demo. Image by author.
If you don't have any pretty pictures readily available, take the time to create them. No need for anything fancy here. For example, in my portfolio (http://redirect.medium.systems/r-9tNmK3Ondx?source=email-f3998e1cd186-1684505410292-newsletter.subscribeToProfile-------------------------b7fc8226_3115_45e7_9573_38a7fca11127--------3ec6dd6333f3)
, I made most of the images using Keynote (i.e. Apple's version of PowerPoint).
Mistake 5: Ignore all non-technical aspects
The data science version of "all chest, no legs."
It's easy to get caught up in all the cool and exciting technical aspects of data science while virtually ignoring all other non-technical aspects.

The over-technical data science portfolio. Image by author.
Although technical skills are absolutely critical, non-technical aspects such as domain knowledge and communication skills are also important. This is especially true if hiring is done by a non-technical audience (which is often the case at smaller organizations without a dedicated data science team).
One simple thing that can help is listing out all the domains in which you've worked. Additionally, having video or written content in which you are presenting a project or technical topic can help convey those critical communication skills.
···
https://medium.com/media/6a565d333330572fa27aa7b3e86f490f/href
